questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with painful blisters over oral mucosa and genital areas. She gives a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Pemphigus Vulgaris.

Points in favor:

  • 40-year female
  • Painful blisters over oral mucosa and genitalia
  • Suprabasal split 
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg3 > Dsg1

Option A: Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Here there will be extremely pruritic vesicular eruptions over extensors.

Immunofluorescence shows Granular IgA deposits along with the dermal papillae.

Option C: Bullous pemphigoid

  • It usually affects elders (60-80 years).
  • Tense subepidermal blisters will be present.
  • No mucosal involvement (unlike pemphigus vulgaris).
  • Immunofluorescence: Linear IgG deposits.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus

  • No mucosal involvement.
  • Subcorneal blisters are seen.
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg1.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the adverse effects characteristic of metoclopramide. The most common adverse effects of metoclopramide involve the central nervous system because it crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blocks the central D2 receptors.

The adverse effects include:

  • Restlessness
  • Drowsiness
  • Insomnia
  • Anxiety
  • Agitation 
  • Extrapyramidal effects - acute reaction with high doses and long-term therapy. (due to central dopamine receptor blockade)
    • Dystonias
    • Akathisia
    • Parkinsonian features
    • Tardive dyskinesia 

Adverse events are more common among the elderly. Long-term use should be avoided unless absolutely necessary.

questions.text: A patient has just been diagnosed with migraine. Which of the following drugs can you prescribe for prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Topiramate is used in the prophylaxis of migraine. Long-term use of topiramate can cause weight loss.

The drugs that have been approved by the FDA for the preventive treatment of migraine include:

  • Propranolol
  • Timolol
  • Sodium valproate
  • Topiramate

Options A and B - Sumatriptan, a 5HT1B/1D agonist is a first-line agent for the termination of acute attacks. Ergotamines are also used in the termination of acute attacks. 

Option C - Domperidone is indicated as an adjuvant in acute attacks. Acute attacks are associated with gastric stasis and an increased incidence of nausea and vomiting. It is helpful in reducing gastrointestinal effects. It can also increase gastrointestinal absorption of other antimigraine agents that are not absorbed due to gastric stasis.

questions.text: A child is brought to the PHC with acute diarrhea. The doctor based on the history suspects that the child may be suffering from an infection due to shigella over cholera. Which of the following points on the history, apart from bloody stools, favors the doctor's suspicion?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the presence of fever favors the suspicion towards Shigella as the infectious agent.

The absence of rectal pain and the presence of vomiting favors cholera while abdominal cramps are present in both of these conditions.

Symptomatic differential diagnosis of shigella and cholera:

Symptoms Cholera Shigella
Diarrhea Acute watery Acute bloody
Fever No Yes
Abdominal cramps Yes Yes
Vomiting Yes No
Rectal pain No Yes
Stool >3 loose stools per day, watery like rice water > 3 stools/day, with blood or pus.

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below.
questions.solution:
The test shown is the cover - uncover test.

 

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and swelling in the right inguinal region and female-type external genitalia. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is 46XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the affected individual has testes producing the androgens, but the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea - Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts - Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region - Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, due to loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix - Due to the production of mullerian inhibiting substance from the sertoli cells of the testis.
  • The XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Option A - Swyer's syndrome : although the karyotype is 46XY, the testes are dysgenetic and do not produce androgens. As a result the external genitalia resemble that of a female. The Mullerian system is preserved as the dysgenetic gonads fail to produce anti Mullerian hormone.

Option C - Mullerian agenesis is another cause of primary amenorrhea characterised by absent uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix and upper vagina. The secondary sexual characteristics are preserved due to the presence of estrogen producing ovaries. However the karyotype is 46XX.

Option D - Turner's syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping reveals 45XO and the individual has streak ovaries and absent secondary sexual features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A patient with dysphagia was evaluated with a barium swallow as given in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers and nitrates are first line therapy
Pneumatic dilatation only provides short term relief
Myotomy of only the affected segment is done
Endoscopic botulinum injection is given when medical therapy is contraindicated

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Myotomy involves the entire length of the affected segment along with a margin of several centimeters to the spastic region to prevent remnants of spasticity. 

First-line therapy is with calcium channel blockers and nitrates. Endoscopic botulinum toxin injection and pneumatic dilation are second-line therapies. Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects.

Botulinum toxin injection is also considered an effective and low-risk procedure but for short-term symptom relief. Pneumatic dilation is targeted at the exact anatomic site of narrowing.

Surgical treatment includes extended myotomy of the esophageal body or peroral endoscopic myotomy. Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a safe and effective treatment for patients, especially those who are refractory to medical therapy.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pain was prescribed a drug that inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog. Mechanism of action is a combination of effects as mentioned below-

  • Weak agonist action on the mu-opioid receptor
  • Inhibition of serotonin reuptake transporter (moderate action) and norepinephrine reuptake transporter (weak action). 

It is used to induce analgesia for moderate pain and can be used as an adjunct to opioid therapy in chronic pain conditions. 

Other options: They do not affect serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake

Option A: Hydromorphone is a phenanthrene drug with strong mu-opioid agonist action with a variable affinity for delta and kappa receptors. It is similar to morphine.  

Option C: Buprenorphine is also a phenanthrene derivative that has mixed opioid agonist-antagonist activity. It is a partial mu-agonist and has antagonist activity at delta and kappa receptors. While it can serve as an analgesic, it antagonizes the action of strong mu-agonists such as morphine. It is used to treat moderate pain and reduced cravings in patients recovering from alcoholism.

Option D: Hydrocodone is a phenanthrene drug with mild-moderate mu-opioid agonist action. It is less efficacious than morphine.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her right hand. Her daily routine involves taking care of her 2 kids. Of late, she feels excruciating pain in certain movements of her hand. On examination, the Finkelstein test is positive. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved in this condition?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the positive Finkelstein's test is suggestive of De Quervain's disease. The structures likely to be involved in this condition are extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test- the examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons. 

The image below shows Finkelstein's test. 


Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs should be stopped in a patient with a creatinine of 5.6 mg/dL?
questions.solution:
Metformin should be stopped in case of elevated creatinine levels (renal insufficiency) > 1.5 mg/dl in men and >1.4 mg/dl in women.

Metformin acts by reducing hepatic glucose production and improves peripheral glucose utilization. Lactic acidosis and Vitamin B12 deficiency are specific adverse effects of metformin. It is not used in patients with a glomerular filtration rate <30 mL/min (moderate renal insufficiency), acidosis, unstable congestive cardiac failure, liver disease, severe hypoxemia, and patients undergoing contrast studies.

questions.text: Metallic body implants are disposed off in which colored bags?
questions.solution:
Metallic body implants and glassware are disposed off in Blue colored bags.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with low-grade fever. On examination, a characteristic slapped cheek appearance is seen on the face. Which of the following describes the genetic makeup of the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the classical slapped cheek appearance, the condition is due to Parvovirus infection also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease. Parvovirus is made up of single-stranded DNA.

Erythema infectiosum:

  • Also known as Fifth disease
  • Incubation period: 4-14 days
  • Rash appears first on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), spreads to the trunk

Clinical features:

  • Child will be febrile, non-toxic with a nonspecific prodrome
  • Transient aplastic anemia, myocarditis
  • Petechial/ purpuric skin eruptions: Papular purpuric “gloves and socks” syndrome (PPGSS)
  • Arthritis and arthralgia
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: Identify the finding in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the foetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

If this part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os, the condition is called vasa previa. In this condition, rupture of the membranes leads to vaginal bleeding and foetal exsanguination.

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The foetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Succenturiate placenta - One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-lactose fermenter?
questions.solution:
Proteus is a non-lactose fermenter.

Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPM SPY

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Morganella
  • Shigella (Except S sonnie which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Yersinia

questions.text: How will you confirm the diagnosis in a patient suspected to have bilhemia?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation for the diagnosis of bilhemia.

Bilhemia is a condition in which bile flows into the bloodstream through the hepatic veins or portal vein branches. This flow occurs due to a high intrabiliary pressure, exceeding that of the venous system.

The cause can be the erosion of gallstones into the portal vein, or accidental/iatrogenic trauma. This condition can be fatal secondary to the embolization of large amounts of bile into the lungs. Usually, bile flow is low, and the fistulas close spontaneously.

Its clinical features include:

  • Rapidly progressive jaundice
  • Marked direct hyperbilirubinemia, without elevation of the hepatocellular enzyme levels.
  • Septicemia.

Diagnosis of bilhemia is best made by ERCP.

Treatment is directed at reducing the intrabiliary pressure through stent placement or sphincterotomy. Endovascular embolization can also be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in heart failure?
questions.solution:
Trimetazidine is not used in heart failure.

Trimetazidine is a newer antianginal drug that is a pFOX inhibitor which partially inhibits the fatty acid oxidation pathway in the myocardium. This decreases the oxygen requirement of the heart.

Nesiritide (natriuretic peptide), sacubitril (neprilysin inhibitor) and metoprolol (beta-blocker) are used in the treatment of heart failure.

questions.text: Following dark green colonies on SDA agar are produced by:
questions.solution:
After 3-4 days incubation on Sabourand agar at 25-37 oC, the colonies have velvety to powdery appearance and are characteristically colored – A.fumigatus – dark green, A.niger – black and A.flavus – yellow-green.

Zygomycetes produce greyish white colonies.

questions.text: What is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis called?
questions.solution:
The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis is called the obstetrical conjugate.

It is clinically important because the fetal head has to pass through this diameter to descend further downwards. It cannot be measured directly. Instead, it is calculated by subtracting 1.5 to 2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. Normally, it measures 10 cm or more.

Other options:

The anatomical or the true conjugate extends from the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.

The diagonal conjugate is measured clinically as the distance between the lowest margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory and is about 1.5-2 cm greater than the obstetrical conjugate.

Description: Antero-posterior diameters at the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: The radiograph of a boy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a champagne glass pelvis and is suggestive of achondroplasia.

Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder resulting in proximal limb shortening (rhizomelic dwarfism). It is the most common cause of disproportionate dwarfism. The iliac blades are flattened giving rise to a pelvic inlet that resembles a champagne glass. The acetabular angles are flattened (horizontal) and the sacrosciatic notch is small.

The image below shows a patient with achondroplasia -

Other options: 

Option A: Perthe's disease is characterized by a flattened and later, fragmented femoral head. 

Option B: Hip dysplasia usually presents with hip dislocation. 

Option C: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) presents with the metaphysis being displaced laterally and not overlapping the posterior lip of the acetabulum as it should normally.

questions.text: A 4-year old child presented with a history of recurrent fractures, without any significant trauma. The child had short stature, scoliosis and bowed arms and legs. The X-ray image is as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray and clinical features are characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Osteogenesis imperfecta also known as "brittle bone" disease, is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal synthesis and structural defects of the type I collagen leading to abnormalities of the bones, teeth, ligaments, sclerae, and skin.

The defining clinical features of OI include:

  • Osteopenia
  • Recurrent Fractures
  • Laxity of Ligaments
  • Bluish Discoloration of The Sclerae
  • Dentinogenesis Imperfecta ("Crumbling Teeth")

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Apolipoprotein E4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: What is the most common karyotype seen in complete mole?
questions.solution:
46 XX is the most common karyotype seen in a complete mole.

It occurs when an ovum with absent or inactivated chromosomes is fertilized by a haploid sperm (23 X) which then duplicates its chromosomes (46 XX) after meiosis.

46 XY karyotype is less commonly seen in complete mole and occurs when an ovum with absent/inactivated chromosomes is fertilised by two sperms (23 X and 23 Y). This is called dispermy.

69 XXY and 69 XXX karyotypes are common in partial mole and are due to fertilization of a haploid ovum by two sperms. 69 XYY karyotype is less common.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A 45-year-old, non diabetic and normotensive man comes with complaints of pain over the heel that is most severe while taking the first step in the morning and aggravated on dorsiflexion. The appropriate diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The above given complaints are suggestive of plantar fasciitis.

The pain is often worse when first getting up in the morning, with typical hobbling downstairs, or when first getting up from a period of sitting – the typical start-up pain and stiffness.

In Achilles tendonitis pain is increased with activity.

In calcaneal stress fractures there may be a history of unaccustomed and repetitive activity or one of a strenuous physical exercise programme. A common sequence of events is: pain after exercise – pain during exercise – pain without exercise.

In tarsal tunnel syndrome, there is pain and sensory disturbance in the medial part of the forefoot, unrelated to weight bearing, may be due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. The pain is often worse at night and the patient may seek relief by walking around or stamping the foot.

questions.text: What is the minimum length that the platform of a well should extend around it in all directions?
questions.solution:
The platform of a sanitary well should stretch for at least 1 metre around the well in all directions.

Related Pearl: Wells

  • Wells are a source of ground water and are widely used across India.
  • The two main types of wells are the shallow and deep wells, the difference between which are:
  Shallow Wells Deep Wells
Description They tap subsoil water, i.e., water from above the first impervious layer in the ground They tap water from the water-bearing stratum which is below the first impervious layer of the ground
Chemical quality Moderately hard water Very hard water
Contamination Very often grossly contaminated and liable to pollution Low contamination levels and purer than water from shallow wells
Yield Generally dry in summer Provides constant water supply
Prevalence in India Very common Less common than shallow wells
  • An artesian well is a type of deep well in which the water rises to the surface due to the pressure with which it is held between two impervious/impermeable layers. There is no pump or other manual methods needed to bring the water to the surface. These are not common in India.
  • Wells can also be classified according to the method of construction as dug wells and tube wells.

i) Dug wells:

  • They are the most common type of wells in India.
  • In rural India, two types of dug wells exist, namely the unlined katcha wells and the masonry or pucca wells.
  • The katcha wells are just big holes dug into the sand.
  • The pucca wells are well built with walls or linings made of brick or stones.
  • Step wells are types of pucca dug wells that have steps. These steps can be used by people to descend into the well and come in contact with water. This increases the risk of water contamination.

ii) Tube wells:

  • Shallow tube wells are also called driven wells and deep tube wells are called bore wells.
  • They are safer sources of water compared to other wells, relatively cheaper to build and maintain.
  • Tube wells use strainers at the bottom and hand pumps at the top attached by a pipe in between.

The following are the considerations for building a safe and sanitary well:

Location Must be at least 15 m away from sources of contamination. Must not be >100 m from households.
Lining Must be made of brick or stones set in cement to a depth of 6 m, so that water enters from bottom and not sides. Height of lining above ground level must be 60 – 90 cm.
Parapet Wall Must be at least 70 – 75 cm (28 inches) from the ground level.
Platform Should stretch at least 1 m around the well in all directions.
Drain It should be a pucca drain to carry spilled water to a public drain beyond the cone of filtration of the well.
Covering There should be a cement concrete covering over the well.
Hand-pump Should be able to withstand rough handling.
Consumer responsibility Consumers must practice basic precautions before handling the well.
Quality The water standards in terms of quality must be conformed to.

questions.text: The translocation characteristic of follicular lymphoma is:
questions.solution:
Majority of the follicular lymphomas have a characteristic (14;18) translocation that fuses the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is tested in Breslau’s second life test?
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test, also known as the stomach bowel test, the stomach and the duodenum are tested.

This test is done to determine whether the baby was born alive or not.

It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live-born child. Detecting the presence of this air in these viscera constitutes the basis for this test.

Procedure :

The stomach and duodenum are removed separately and placed in water. If they float, make a small cut while underwater to see air bubbles coming up. A floating viscera giving out air bubbles when opened underwater is a positive test.

Interpretation:

  • A positive test proves live birth even in the absence of a positive hydrostatic lung test. This may happen if there had been some obstruction in the respiratory passages.
  • A negative test does not mean stillbirth since air does not necessarily enter the stomach in adequate amounts during the breathing act.
  • Putrefaction invalidates the result.

Note: Breslau’s first life test is when the same test is performed on the lungs. Also known as Hydrostatic test/ Floatation test / Raygat’s test.

questions.text: Acute inflammatory response is not seen in:
questions.solution:
An inflammatory response is not seen in apoptosis. In this process, the cell membrane remains intact. Hence, there is no leakage of cell contents and no surrounding inflammation.
 
On the other hand, other forms of cell death including necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve the disintegration of the cell membrane. This causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought to the emergency with symptoms of cyanosis, rapid breathing, and failure to thrive. The chest X-ray of the child is given below. Probable diagnosis is ____________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a snowman or figure of 8 appearance. The probable diagnosis in the above case is Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection.

TAPVC: Pulmonary veins instead of draining into left atrium drain into right atrium directly or indirectly. Following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior vena cava or the left innominate vein
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with burning pain on passing urine. He reluctantly admits that he had unprotected sexual intercourse 3 days ago. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient occurring 3 days after unprotected sex point to urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as its incubation period is 1-5 days.

The most common presentation of gonococcal infection in men is acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Pharyngeal and rectal infections can also occur depending on the type of sexual contact.

The primary site of infection in women is the cervix but the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may be involved. Symptoms include excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital and intermenstrual bleeding.

The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia, which has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks. It usually presents with dysuria alone, but mucopurulent discharge can occur. Other causes of NGU are Mycoplasma genitalium and Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: Which of the following best defines the type of enzyme inhibition by malonate on succinate dehydrogenase reaction?
questions.solution:
Inhibition of succinate dehydrogenase reaction by malonate is an example of competitive inhibition.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency.

Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, and inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes.

Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

questions.solution:
Only IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine in the given options.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primiparous woman came to the OPD with complaints of nausea and vomiting at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is specifically indicated to provide symptomatic relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
Doxylamine is indicated with pyridoxine to reduce mild to moderate nausea and vomiting in the early stages of pregnancy.

It is a histamine H1 antagonist and its efficacy is improved when combined with pyridoxine.

Combinations of domperidone, dolasetron and metoclopramide with pyridoxine are not specifically indicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: When is the ideal time to repair old complete perineal tears which had occurred during delivery?
questions.solution:
In case of an old complete perineal tear, the optimum time for operative repair is after 3-6 months post-delivery.

The best time of repair is, however, within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, then the better option is to do it 3-6 months after delivery. By 3 months' time, the local infection subsides, the general condition of the patient improves and the baby can be kept at home. If kept for more than 6 months, there is more fibrosis on the margins and unnecessary prolonged inconvenience to the patient.

Perineal repair after an episiotomy or spontaneous obstetric laceration is one of the most common surgical procedures. Obstetric perineal lacerations are classified as first to fourth degree, depending on their depth.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for theophylline?
questions.solution:
Theophylline is indicated in the treatment of apnea of prematurity.

In apnea of prematurity, methylxanthines such as theophylline and caffeine increase the central respiratory drive by lowering the threshold of response to hypercapnia. They also enhance the contractility of the diaphragm and prevent diaphragmatic fatigue.

Options A & B - The adenosine receptor antagonism property of theophylline precipitates cardiac arrhythmias and epileptic seizures. 

Option C - Theophylline is no longer recommended as a treatment for acute severe asthma by the latest guidelines (GINA 2021) because of its poor efficacy and safety profile.

questions.solution:
The given tympanogram shows A - abnormally low compliance seen in Otosclerosis and; B - no peak in compliance as seen when fluid is in the middle ear.

questions.text: While reviewing the drug chart of a patient undergoing radiotherapy, which of the following drugs would require a dose adjustment to prevent radiation toxicity?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin requires dose adjustment during or after radiotherapy in order to prevent radiation toxicity.

Anthracyclines like doxorubicin can result in a radiation recall reaction, where erythema and desquamation of skin are observed at sites of previous radiation injury. The risk of cardiotoxicity also increases with previous irradiation. Therefore, careful monitoring and dosage adjustments are required for doxorubicin.

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady was started on an ocular medication that she was instructed to take daily. She develops redness of the eye. Examination reveals a colour change of the iris and orbital fat atrophy. Which of the following medications was she likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a patient that has iris pigmentation and redness of the eye, was most likely started on latanoprost.

Drug Side Effects
Latanoprost

Allergic conjunctival hyperemia, permanent increase in iris pigmentation, orbital fat atrophy.
Timolol  Exacerbation of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, impotence

questions.text: The rhythm strip shows:
questions.solution:
The above EKG shows:

  • Heart rate > 100
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

Multifocal AT (MAT) is characterized by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

There is no risk of thromboembolism in MAT.

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

Rhythm is regular. Rate is 150-200 bpm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex.

PSVT can occur in a normal heart. Drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Atrial fibrillation:

Rhythm is irregularly irregular. Rate is >300 bpm. P wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of A. Fib.

Atrial flutter:

Rhythm is regular. Rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of seizures. Examination revealed delayed milestones. Chest and abdominal examination showed no significant findings. Fundoscopy revealed the following image. The enzyme that could be deficient in the child is:
questions.solution:
The presence of seizures, developmental delay, and cherry-red spots in the fundus (seen in the image), in an infant without hepatosplenomegaly, is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, which is due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A.

In this condition, there is an accumulation of the lipid ganglioside. Other features include mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness. 

Other options:

Option A: β-Glucosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease, which commonly has a combination of developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly with the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency leads to Niemann-Pick disease, where infants exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, interstitial lung disease, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option D: α-Galactosidase deficiency leads to Fabry disease, which has symptoms of skin rash, kidney, heart failure, and burning pain in the lower extremities.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organisms shown below acts via?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and a Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: What is the most common indication for liver transplant in children?
questions.solution:
The most common indication for liver transplant in children is biliary atresia. 

In biliary atresia, the extrahepatic bile ducts are occluded, causing obstructive jaundice (conjugated hyper-bilirubinemia) and progressive liver fibrosis in early infancy. Liver transplantation is required if not diagnosed and managed early.

(option B) Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a progressive liver failure in young children, associated with marked hepatic copper overload (in excess of 800 μg/g dry weight). Unlike Wilson disease, ICC is associated with normal or elevated ceruloplasmin levels, indicating a defect late in the copper excretory pathway.

questions.text: The amount of sodium present in ReSoMal is ________
questions.solution:
Rehydration solution for malnourished (ReSoMal) contains 45 mmol/L of sodium.

Severely malnourished children have excess intracellular sodium (leaky cell membranes and reduced activity of the sodium–potassium pump). So, sodium intake should be reduced and a low-sodium oral rehydration solution (ReSoMal) is advised. Because severely malnourished children are deficient in potassium, ReSoMal contains extra potassium, as well as extra glucose or sucrose and selected minerals (Mg, Cu, Zn).

questions.text: The following process where transportation is along the concentration gradient is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a glucose transporter that transports glucose from a higher concentration to a lower concentration. This is an example of facilitated diffusion. 

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Glucose transporters also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions inside the cell membrane by binding to a carrier/ transport protein. 

For example, insulin stimulates glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane. This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues. 

Other options - 

Option A. Simple diffusion - It is along the concentration gradient but is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Option C. Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against a membrane with chemical or electrical gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option D. In secondary active transport, the active transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances. Examples include the symport of sodium with glucose (luminal membranes of mucosal cells in the small intestine), and Ca2+ in the cardiac muscle cells.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with diarrhea, bloody stools, weight loss, and intermittent fever for the past 2 months. Endoscopy revealed the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation along with the endoscopy image showing a cobblestone appearance are suggestive of Crohn's disease (CD).

Endoscopic findings in Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers - small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's disease. 

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain and breathlessness after a road traffic accident. No penetrating injury to the chest is seen. His chest X-ray is as given below. Which of the following is an indication for thoracotomy?

choices.text: Persistence of hemothorax despite a tube thoracostomy
Continuous bleeding < 50 ml/h for 3 consecutive hours
Drainage of > 1500 ml blood when chest tube is first inserted

questions.solution:
Drainage of >1500 ml blood when the chest tube is first inserted is an indication for thoracotomy.

The above clinical scenario with the chest radiograph showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification of the half of the hemithorax is suggestive of hemothorax. 

Thoracotomy is a creation of access to contents of the thoracic cavity by an incision between the ribs.

The indications for thoracotomy in a thoracic trauma are:

  • Drainage of more than 1500 ml (blunt trauma) or 1000ml (penetrating trauma) blood when the chest tube is first inserted
  • Continuous hemorrhage of more than 200 mL/h for 3 consecutive hours (Option C)
  • Caked hemothorax (Persistence of hemothorax despite two tube thoracotomies) (Option B)
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Inadequate ventilation with a massive air leak in chest tube
  • Trachea or main stem bronchial injury(diagnosed on imaging or endoscopy)
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Esophageal perforation
  • Air embolism

Other options:

Option A- Surgical emphysema is a common phenomenon complication tube thoracostomy for pneumothorax. It is usually benign, self-limiting that requires only conservative treatment.

questions.text: During rounds in the postnatal ward, you notice a patient's case sheet mentioning she had uterine tachysystole following labor induction. What is the criteria for this diagnosis?

choices.text: More than  5 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 5 contractions in a 10-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 10-min period

questions.solution:
Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10 min period and may occur in spontaneous or stimulated labor. It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal heart rate abnormalities. Tachysystole interrupts maternal blood flow to the placenta during contractions and may lead to a reduction in fetal oxygenation. It is also associated with placental abruption.

It is caused by pharmacological agents used for cervical ripening and induction such as misoprostol (both oral and vaginal) and dinoprostone. Management includes stopping oxytocin infusion and terbutaline 0.25 mg SC.

questions.text: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease. 

Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

The following image shows Maltese cross casts:

Note: Maltese cross appearance is also seen in short-range shotgun wounds and babesiosis.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the OPD with infertility and amenorrhea. She also complains of milky discharge from the nipple. Her urine pregnancy test was negative and her prolactin level was 45 ng/ml. Which of the following drugs cannot lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
This given scenario of infertility, amenorrhea and galactorrhea with elevated prolactin level (normal level is 0-25 ng/ml in a non-pregnant woman) is suggestive of hyperprolactinemia, and bromocriptine does not lead to hyperprolactinemia. It is a dopamine-agonist and hence it inhibits prolactin synthesis.

Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia.

Related Pearl: Drugs causing hyperprolactinemia

  • Dopamine receptor blockers:
    • Atypical antipsychotics: Risperidone
    • Phenothiazines: Chlorpromazine, perphenazine
    • Butyrophenones: Haloperidol
    • Thioxanthenes
    • Metoclopramide
  • Dopamine synthesis inhibitors:
    • α-Methyldopa
  • Catecholamine depletors:
    • Reserpine
  • Opiates

 

  • H2 antagonists:
    • Cimetidine, ranitidine
  • Imipramines:
    • Amitriptyline, amoxapine
  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors:
    • Fluoxetine
  • Calcium channel blockers:
    • Verapamil
  • Estrogens

 

  • Thyrotropin-releasing hormone

questions.text: Which of the following is not a histone deacetylase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Febuxostat is a uric acid synthesis inhibitor that acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase and it is indicated in gout management.

Examples of histone deacetylase inhibitors are:

  • Vorinostat - cutaneous T cell lymphoma
  • Belinostat - peripheral T cell lymphoma
  • Romidepsin - cutaneous/peripheral T cell lymphoma
  • Panobinostat - multiple myeloma

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 months. Fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%, and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a well-defined 1 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. The treatment plan should be _______.
questions.solution:
Recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is suggestive of insulinoma. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. 

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide.

questions.text: A person with myasthenia gravis notes increased muscle strength when he is treated with an acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor.  The basis for his improvement is due to the increase in _______

choices.text: The amount of acetylcholine (ACh) released from motor nerves
The level of ACh at the muscle end plates
The number of ACh receptors on the motor end plates
Synthesis of norepinephrine in motor nerves

questions.solution:
Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate.

Myasthenia gravis:

  • It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor.
  • Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number of ACh receptors on the muscle end plate.
  • The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced.
  • Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reduced number of receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about congenital rubella syndrome (CRS)?

choices.text: Demonstration of IgM antibodies in infants is diagnostic
Infection during the second trimester carries highest risk for CRS
The classic triad includes cataract, cardiac abnormalities, and deafness
At birth, the virus is detectable in pharyngeal secretions

questions.solution:
Infection during the first trimester is associated with the highest incidence (85%) of cases of congenital rubella syndrome, followed by infections in second trimester (16% of cases). Maternal infection after 20 weeks of gestation is rarely associated with the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Maternal IgM antibodies against the rubella virus does not cross the placenta. Therefore, the presence of IgM rubella antibodies in infants is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome.  In contrast, the maternal IgG antibodies may be transferred to the infants and may be detectable for about 6 months.

Option c: The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease (Most commonly: patent ductus arteriosus)

Option d: At birth, the virus is detectable in pharyngeal secretions, multiple organs, cerebrospinal fluid, urine, and rectal swabs.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A primi presented to the hospital for the first time in active labour and was found to be HIV positive. She had not taken any drugs for the same. According to the NACO guidelines, what is the minimum duration for which nevirapine is given to the infant if breastfeeding is practised?
questions.solution:
Nevirapine prophylaxis has to be given for a minimum period of 12 weeks, as the mother has not taken ART in the antenatal period and the infant is to be breastfed.

The dose of syrup Nevirapine (10 mg/ml solution) for ARV prophylaxis in infants is as given below:

Infant age

Daily dose 

Birth to 6 weeks (based on birth weight)

  2000-2500 g

10 mg (1 ml) 

>2500 g

 15 mg (1.5 ml)

>6 weeks - up to 6 months

20 mg (2 ml)

>6 months - up to 9 months

30 mg (3 ml)

>9 months

40 mg (4 ml)

The duration of prophylaxis depends on the HIV risk status of the infant.

  • Low-risk infants are born to mothers with suppressed plasma viral loads assessed after 32 weeks. They require prophylaxis from birth till 6 weeks.

  • High-risk infants are born to mothers with unsuppressed or unknown plasma viral loads assessed after 32 weeks, newly diagnosed HIV-positive mothers, or those not on ART. They require prophylaxis from birth till 6 weeks if exclusive replacement feeding is done and till 12 weeks if exclusive breastfeeding is practiced.

questions.text: All of the following anti fungal drugs inhibit ergosterol synthesis except __________
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B binds ergosterol in the fungal membrane and disrupts the structural integrity by forming channels and pores resulting in fungicidal action. It has no action on ergosterol synthesis. 

Options A and B: Ketoconazole and fluconazole are imidazole and triazole antigungal agents that act by inhibiting 14 alpha sterol demethylase resulting in impairment of ergosterol synthesis.

Option D: Terbinafine is an allylamine that inhibits squalene epoxidase and reduces ergosterol synthesis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Which is a mood stabiliser with an anti-suicidal role?
questions.solution:
Lithium is a mood stabilizer with an antisuicidal role.

Maintenance treatment with lithium has shown to decrease the rate of suicide in mood disorders. Lithium was found to be better than other mood stabilizers such as carbamazepine, lamotrigine, and valproate.

Lithium is also used in recurrent depression with a cyclic pattern is controlled by either lithium or imipramine. It is also used to augment standard antidepressant response in acute major depression in those patients who have had an inadequate response to monotherapy.

questions.text: All of the following local anesthetics have a long duration of action, except ______.
questions.solution:
All the given options have a long duration of action except lidocaine, which has an intermediate duration of action.

Lidocaine is a local anesthetic that is widely used wherever an agent with an intermediate duration of action is needed. When given along with epinephrine, lidocaine's action is prolonged because of decreased absorption. 

Tetracaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine are long-acting local anesthetics.

Local anesthetics are agents that cause a reversible loss of sensory/motor paralysis in a restricted area. Clinically, they can be used for:

  • topical - direct application of the aqueous solution to mucous membranes
  • infiltration - direct injection of agent to tissue
  • field block - subcutaneous injection to anesthetize region distal to the injection
  • nerve block - injection directly onto peripheral nerves/ nerve plexus 
  • intravenous (Bier's block) - relies on vasculature to anesthetize nerve trunk and endings
  • spinal - injected into CSF in lumbar space
  • epidural - injected into epidural space 

Related Pearl: Classification of local anesthetics based on duration of action

Short duration of action ( 20-45 minutes):

  • Procaine
  • Chloroprocaine

Intermediate duration ( 60-120 minutes):

  • Lidocaine
  • Mepivacaine
  • Prilocaine

Long duration (400-450 minutes):

  • Tetracaine
  • Bupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine
  • Etidocaine

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

Related Pearl: Classification of Local Anesthetics based on the Potency

  1. Low Potency - Procaine
  2. Intermediate Potency
    • Mepivacaine
    • Prilocaine
    • Chloroprocaine
    • Lidocaine
  3. High Potency
    • Tetracaine
    • Bupivacaine
    • Etidocaine

questions.text: The finding shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows blue sclera which is seen in Marfan syndrome. Here, the blue tinge is due to the uveal pigment shining through a thin sclera.

Other conditions associated with blue sclera include:

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta – Type I and type IIA
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome – Type VI
  • Congenital glaucoma
  • Healed scleritis
  • High myopia
  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum
  • Nevus of Ota

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcers underwent an upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy was stained with a special stain as shown in the image. Identify the special stain used.
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the Helicobacter pylori bacilli.

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin-Starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

The image given below is GI biopsy stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

The below image is a Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of ranolazine?
questions.solution:
The predominant mechanism of action of ranolazine is inhibition of the late sodium current in myocardial cells.

Ranolazine is useful for patients with chronic angina despite standard medical therapy. It is administered at a dose of 500-1000 mg twice daily.

Contraindications:

  • Hepatic impairment
  • QT prolongation
  • Drugs inhibiting CYP3A metabolic system- ketoconazole, diltiazem, verapamil, macrolide antibiotics, HIV protease inhibitors, and large quantities of grapefruit juice

questions.text: What parameters are used in calculating discriminant function?

choices.text: Prothrombin time, ascites and hepatic encephalopathy

questions.solution:
Discriminant function (DF) is calculated using prothrombin time and bilirubin level. It is also known as the Maddrey score and it assesses the severity and mortality risk in alcoholic hepatitis. 

DF = 4.6 X (the prolongation of the prothrombin time above control [seconds]) + serum bilirubin (mg/dL)

DF ≥ 32 indicates severe disease and is an indication for starting glucocorticoids.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with complaints of urinary incontinence. His history is notable for increasing forgetfulness and the physical examination reveals an abnormal gait. His fundus looks normal, he has no tremors.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with dementia, ataxia (gait disturbance), and urinary incontinence which is suggestive of Normal pressure hydrocephalus. 

NPH may be caused by obstruction to normal CSF flow over the cerebral convexities and delayed resorption into the venous system. This results in enlarged lateral ventricles with relatively little increase in CSF pressure. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of:

  • Dementia (mostly executive function)
  • Ataxic or apractic gait
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too)

On imaging, dilated lateral ventricles are seen. Lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the normal to high range.

Treatment includes ventricular shunting. Gait improves more than cognition.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought by his mother with growth failure and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations revealed a hemoglobin of  8 g/dL and normal levels of vitamin B12 and B9. His peripheral smear is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing hypersegmented neutrophils with normal vitamin B12 and B9 levels is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare autosomal recessive condition. It occurs due to an error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine resulting in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. It is of two types:

  • Type I - deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase)
  • Type II - deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Children clinically present with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intellectual disability.

Confirmation of the diagnosis requires an assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patient's red blood cells. Anemia responds well to the administration of uridine.

Other options:

Option A: Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. It is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It usually presents as painful monoarthritis that mainly involves the metatarsophalangeal joints of the first toe.

Option B: Severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) occurs due to a deficiency in adenosine deaminase, an enzyme of purine metabolism. This results in the accumulation of adenosine metabolites. This causes premature cell death of B, T and NK cells. Children with SCID present with recurrent oral candidiasis, failure to thrive, diarrhea and interstitial pneumonitis.

Option D: Copper deficiency is usually seen in a condition called Menkes kinky hair syndrome. Children usually present with intellectual disability, hypocupremia, and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
The rate of the given ECG is around 188 BPM ( >100 BPM) and it shows wide QRS complexes ( ≥ 0.12 s) with abnormal morphology (red arrows) and absence of P waves which suggests a diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option B) would not show discreet QRS complexes, and hence is not the answer in this case.

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: A primigravida underwent a quadruple screening test at 16 weeks of gestation. All the parameters were low except for serum inhibin A level which was normal. Identify the condition in which the findings given above are seen.
questions.solution:
All the parameters like maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta HCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced in trisomy 18/Edwards syndrome. Maternal serum inhibin A level may be normal or reduced.

Quadruple testing is usually done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. This test can additionally help in picking up Smith-Lemli-Optiz syndrome. However, one of the limitations of the test is that it fails to detect trisomy 13. 

In trisomy 21 and neural tube defects, the changes in the screening markers are as follows:

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG  Beta HCG  Beta HCG 
PAPP-A  Unconjugated estriol  Unconjugated estriol 
This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG MSAFP  MSAFP 
  Serum inhibin A

questions.text: The incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in non smokers. Based on the data given, calculate the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, take the incidence among non-exposed as x and the incidence among exposed as 5x.
  • The attributable risk would be given as [(5x – x)/5x] x 100.
  • Thus, the attributable risk is 80%.
  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A Forensic Examiner receives the following skull of a victim of mob violence. Which of the following conclusions he makes is correct:

choices.text: The victim could have suffered blunt force trauma
It is not possible to determine the sequence of injuries from fracture pattern
The victim could only have suffered from a gun-shot wound as indicated by Puppe’s rule
Fracture pattern in skull injuries are random and offer no clue upon examination

questions.solution:
Puppe’s Rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, and it is of particular importance in Gunshot wounds. But the rule is not limited to gunshots.

Puppe’s rule:

A new fracture Line does not cross an existing fracture line which can be used to determine the sequence of injuries.

In this scenario, the sufferer has been a victim of mob violence and the sequence of injuries would be as mentioned below.

  •  Correct sequence of the injuries in this would be 1->2->3

Note - Puppe's rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force trauma causing skull fractures.

questions.text: Which is the last fontanelle to close?
questions.solution:
The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close. It closes at around 18-24 months of age.

Fontanelles of the skull:

Fontanelle  Location Closes at 
Anterior

Between frontal and parietal bones

Junction marked by bregma

 18-24 months 
Posterior Sagittal and lambdoid sutures 2-3 months
Sphenoid Pterion 2-3 months
Mastoid/Posterolateral Intersection of temporal, parietal, and occipital bones. 6-18 months (average 12 months)

questions.text: A primigravida presented with severe abdominal pain and fever at 28 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals a healthy fetus in utero and a large submucosal fibroid with multiple, hyperechoic areas within. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid. 

It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. The gross appearance is described as follows:

  • Fishy odor
  • Thrombosis of subcapsular vessels and vessels within the fibroid
  • Purplish-red color due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels.

Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.

The image given below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration of fibroids

Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen, but fever and leukocytosis are absent.

Option C: Infection is more common in puerperium and presents with blood-stained vaginal discharge.

Option D: Sarcomatous changes occur very rarely, and are unlikely in patients <40 years of age. They are more commonly seen in post-menopausal women.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of the inability to extend the fingers of his right hand. On examination, the patient was able to extend his right elbow and right wrist, but there was a loss of sensation in the area of the hand as shown in the image below. Where could be the possible site of injury?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical presentation, the site of injury is the lateral epicondyle.

  • The inability to extend fingers with the ability to extend the wrist and elbow indicates injury to the nerve supplying the extensor digitorum and extensor digiti minimi, which is posterior interosseus nerve.
  • Loss of sensation of the skin over the dorsolateral aspect of the palm and the dorsal aspect of lateral 3 and ½ digits up to the terminal interphalangeal joint indicates injury to the superficial branch of the radial nerve.

Since both the superficial branch and deep branches of the radial nerve are involved, the likely site of injury would be lateral epicondyle.

Other options:

  • Injuries around the axilla and radial groove will cause an inability in elbow and wrist extension, and in injuries around the proximal part of the radius, superficial branch of the radial nerve will be spared.

 

The course of the radial nerve:

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve

Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
