Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

questions.text: As per the national immunization schedule, which vaccines are indicated at the first visit for immunization of a 13-month-old baby who has not been previously immunized?

choices.text: BCG, OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Rota virus 1st dose
OPV 1st dose, Pentavalent 1st dose, Measles 1st dose
OPV 1st dose, DPT 1st dose, Measles 1st dose

questions.solution:
DPT-1, OPV-1 and Measles 1st dose will be given to this child.

BCG can only be given upto 1 years of age, according to the National Immunisation Schedule. BCG will not be given to this child, if the National Immunisation Schedule is followed.

Please note that BCG can be given upto 5 years of age, as part of the catch-up immunization schedule, which is put forth by the Indian Academy of Paediatrics and that is not followed in government setups.

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given till 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Pentavalent vaccine can be given only upto the age of 1 year.

World Immunization Week, observed in the last week of April, aims to highlight the collective action needed and to promote the use of vaccines to protect people of all ages against disease. WHO collaborates globally to raise awareness and support governments in implementing quality immunization programs. The ultimate goal of World Immunization Week is for more people – and their communities – to be protected from vaccine-preventable diseases.

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except:
questions.solution:
Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

Hemangioblastomas are tumors of central nervous system that originate from vascular tissues. They demonstrate the proliferation of capillaries with variable sized, closely packed, and thin walled vessels as seen in the image below.

Small round blue cell tumors consist of small round cells that stain blue on routine H&E staining sections. They include:

  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor
  • Rhabdomyosarcomas
  • Acute leukemia

The following is the image of neuroblastoma showing Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by:
questions.solution:
Flask shaped ulcers are classically seen in amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

In amoebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts, and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements.
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus and heme-positive stool.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers.
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography,computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant with large corneas, lacrimation and photophobia supported with the image is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) also known as developmental glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure(IOP) which results from the developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber.

It can be classified as:

  • True congenital or newborn glaucoma in which IOP is elevated during intrauterine life and the baby is born with ocular enlargement.
  • Infantile glaucoma: which manifests prior to age 3 years.
  • Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Clinical findings include:

  • Blepharospasm
  • Buphthalmos: Large eyeball due to stretching of the globe from elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Corneal enlargement:
  • Corneal haze is due to corneal edema.
  • Blue sclera - due to the shining of the underlying uveal tissue through the thinned-out sclera
  • Haab striae are healed breaks in Descemet's membrane

Treatment:

  • Goniotomy - when the angle of the anterior chamber is visible through the clear cornea.
  • Trabeculectomy when the corneal clouding prevents visualization of the angle.
  • Filtration procedures such as Trabeculectomy or combined trabeculectomy with trabeculectomy if the above procedures fail.
  • Glaucoma drainage devices in unresponsive cases.

Other options:

Option A: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood that is seen between 1-2 years.

Findings of Retinoblastoma include:

  • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex)- the most common manifestation
  • Strabismus 
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • An endophytic tumor grows into the vitreous as a white mass that may ‘seed’ into the gel. If calcification is present it gives a "cottage cheese appearance". An exophytic tumor grows outwards and causes overlying exudative retinal detachment.

The image below shows the leucocoria of the left eye.

Option C: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED) is an inherited corneal dystrophy that manifests since birth with endothelial degeneration. It appears as diffuse bilateral corneal edema in the absence of elevated IOP. The clinical features of the disease include corneal clouding, visual impairment, and nystagmus.

Option D: Megalocornea is a bilateral non-progressive X-linked condition that most commonly affects males. In this condition, the horizontal corneal diameter is ≥12mm(<2 years) and is ≥13 mm(>2 years). It is characterized by a clear cornea, normal corneal thickness, and no breaks in the descemet's membrane. Systemic associations of Megalocornea include Marfan's syndrome, Apert syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos, and Down syndrome.

questions.text: A young boy presented with a cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that gives the appearance of a frog’s belly. A ranula usually resolves spontaneously.  

A plunging ranula is a mucus retention cyst. It has mucus collecting below the gland and perforating through the mylohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.  

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

Related Pearl: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

  • It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid
  • Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.
  • Conditions with cross fluctuation are :
    • Plunging ranula
    • Bilocular hydrocele
    • Compound palmar ganglion
    • Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

questions.text: A nurse in the pulmonology clinic administered a test using the following instrument. Which of the following parameters cannot be measured?
questions.solution:
The given image shows spirometry. All of the given parameters can be measured by a spirometer except residual volume.

Residual volume is measured by:

  • N2 washout method
  • Helium-dilution method
  • Body plethysmography

Other parameters which cannot be measured by spirometry are:

  • Functional residual capacity
  • Total lung capacity

questions.text: Which of the following are climbing fibers?
questions.solution:
Climbing fibers are olivocerebellar fibers. They originate from the inferior olivary nucleus. 

Climbing fibers and mossy fibers are the two main excitatory inputs to the cerebellum.

Climbing fibres Mossy fibres
They come from one single source via the inferior olivary nuclei. They come from many sources and the fibers synapse with granule cells to form glomeruli.

End on single Purkinje cells.

Convey proprioceptive inputs from all over the body.

 Axons of granule cells bifurcate and form parallel fibers which excite multiple Purkinje cells.

Note: Mossy fibres provide direct input via the pontine nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following is decreased in haemolytic anaemia?
questions.solution:
Haptoglobin levels decrease in hemolytic anemia.

Haptoglobin is synthesized by the liver. It binds to free hemoglobin and prevents its excretion in urine. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex is rapidly destroyed by the mononuclear phagocytes. Hence, haptoglobin levels decrease in the presence of free hemoglobin as seen in hemolytic anemia.

LDH, free Hb, and methemoglobin are elevated in hemolysis.

questions.text: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a late complication caused by infection with?
questions.solution:
SSPE (subacute sclerosing panencephalitis), also known as Dawson disease is caused by infection with measles virus.

  • It is a slowly progressive disease characterized by seizures and progressive deterioration of cognitive and motor functions, with death occurring 5–15 years after measles virus infection.
  • MIBE: Measles inclusion body encephalitis is a rare but fatal complication that affects individuals with defective cellular immunity and typically occurs months after measles infection.

questions.text: A patient comes with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following is not done?
questions.solution:
Platelet transfusion is not done in the case of active variceal bleeding unless coagulopathy is confirmed as the cause. Platelet transfusions are indicated only in patients with a platelet count of <50,000/microL  or in patients with evidence of microvascular bleeding.

Variceal hemorrhage is a medical emergency. Varices usually present with the acute onset large-volume haematemesis, the lower esophagus being the most common site for variceal bleeding.

The sites for portosystemic anastomosis are:

  • Left gastric vein to distal oesophageal veins: oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding
  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: hemorrhoids and rectal bleeding
  • Left branch of the portal vein to Periumbilical veins: caput-medusae
  • The right branch of the portal vein to retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal, and phrenic veins
  • Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures

Medical management of variceal bleeding includes blood transfusion (option B) and drug therapy with somatostatin analogs like octreotide (option C). Short-term antibiotics like ceftriaxone are known to decrease bacterial infection and increase survival.

Surgical measures are preferred if medical management fails. They include balloon tamponade, endoscopic banding (option D), transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), portosystemic shunts, splenectomy, and gastric revascularization

Note: Sugiura procedure is the non-shunt surgical management of refractory oesophageal variceal bleeding. It is a procedure of de-vascularizing the distal esophagus and stomach.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: The transpulmonary pressure is the pressure difference between _______
questions.solution:
Transpulmonary pressure is intra-alveolar pressure minus intrapleural pressure. (Mnemonic TAP: Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Pleural pressure)

It is the pressure difference between that in the alveoli and that on the outer surfaces of the lungs, and it is a measure of the elastic forces in the lungs that tend to collapse the lungs at each instant of respiration, called the recoil pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best way to detect minimum pneumoperitoneum on X-ray in a patient with abdominal trauma?

choices.text: Right lateral decubitus chest X-ray with horizontal beam
Left lateral decubitus abdomen X-ray with horizontal beam

questions.solution:
Among the given options, the left lateral decubitus X-ray of the abdomen is the best view to visualize the pneumoperitoneum.

As little as 1 mL of free gas can be detected on a plain radiograph. Hence the best views to visualize pneumoperitoneum:

  • Erect chest X-ray - the first, most important and useful view showing air beneath the diaphragm. 
  • Left lateral decubitus abdominal image

CT abdomen is the most sensitive imaging technique to detect minimal pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: A 13-year-old child who weighs 70 kg weight and is a known case of hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 13 year old obese child with hypothyroidism with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip and tenderness in Scarpa's triangle points towards a diagnosis of slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE).

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

  • Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign. Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck.

 

Other options-

Option A: Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

Option C: Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option D: Fracture neck of the femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include comorbidities (diabetes, chronic kidney, and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors).

questions.text: Two potential devices that eukaryotic cells use to regulate transcription are _______
questions.solution:
Two potential devices that eukaryotic cells use to regulate transcription are as follows DNA methylation and histone acetylation.

DNA methylation occurs by methyltransferases that use S-adenosyl-methionine as the methyl donor. It silences gene expression.

Histone acetylation decrease the positive charge on histone proteins, thus decreasing the strength of their association with negatively charged DNA. This chromatin remodeling relaxes the nucleosome, allowing transcription factors access to specific regions on the DNA. Thus, histone acetylation improves gene expression. 

Note: In both eukaryotes and prokaryotes, gene expression is primarily regulated at the level of transcription.

questions.text: Drug efflux forms the primary mode of resistance formation in which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Efflux pumping of the drug is the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine. It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1).

Ciprofloxacin and indinavir develop resistant mainly by reduced affinity to the altered target. 

Resistance to tetracyclines and glycylcyclines occurs by 3 mechanisms:

  • Decreased accumulation or antibiotic efflux
  • Ribosomal protection protein that displaces the drug from its target
  • Enzymatic inactivation of the drug

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy complains of being bullied in school for his high-pitched voice. A Gutzmann’s pressure test is done which helps you to diagnose his condition. What condition does he have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a positive Gutzmann’s pressure test is suggestive of puberphonia.

It is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the prepubertal high pitched voice.

Gutzmann's pressure test is positive when pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and produces a low tone voice. The treatment is speech therapy.

questions.text: A woman with 31 weeks of gestation presents with lower abdominal pain. The clinician is concerned if the patient is in preterm labor. Which of the following is the most appropriate test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Fibronectin detection in cervicovaginal secretions before membrane rupture is a possible marker for impending preterm labor.

Fetal fibronectin:

  • Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein present in high concentrations in maternal blood and in amniotic fluid.
  • Fetal fibronectin levels are measured using ELISA, and values exceeding 50 ng/mL are considered positive.

Screening tests in pregnancy:

1st Trimester:

Dual test + nuchal translucency

DUAL test Down’s syndrome Trisomy 18
PAPP-A (pregnancy associated plasma protein A) ↓ ↓
β-HCG ↑ ↓

 

2nd Trimester:

Quadraple test Down’s syndrome Trisomy 18
α feto protein ↓ ↓
β-HCG ↑ ↓
Estriol (unconjugated E3) ↓ ↓
Inhibin A ↑ ↓

Integrated screening:
Dual screening + nuchal translucency + quad test

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic:
questions.solution:
The image given represents propagated epidemic which results from "person to person transmission".

Single exposure / Point source epidemic Common source / Continuous epidemic Propagated epidemic
A sharp rise and sharp fall in the number of cases Sharp rise in the number of cases Gradual rise and gradual fall over a long time
Clustering of cases in a narrow interval of time such that all cases develop within one incubation period of the disease A fall in the number of cases is interrupted by "secondary waves/peaks" Results from "person-to-person transmission"

Eg: Food poisoning, Measles, Chickenpox, Cholera, Bhopal Gas tragedy

 Eg: Contaminated well in a village, Prostitute in a gonorrhoea outbreak, Legionnaire's disease outbreak in Philadelphia Eg: HIV, TB 

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

questions.text: A study was conducted on the effectiveness of a keto diet for weight loss. Weight of the participants was measured before starting the keto diet and after 1 month of the keto diet.  Which of the following is the most appropriate test to test the statistical significance of the change in weight?
questions.solution:
Since the effect of keto diet is checked on the same individuals, before and after the keto diet, therefore the test used is paired t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: What does the given barium swallow film show?
questions.solution:
The given barium swallow film shows an outpouching from the posterior wall of the pharynx suggestive of a Zenker's diverticulum (pharyngeal pouch). 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

 

Diverticula Weak space Site
Zenker diverticulum Killian triangle/ Killian dehiscence

Above the upper esophageal sphincter

Between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle
Laimer's diverticulum Laimer’s triangle/ Laimer–Hackermann’s area

Posteriorly below cricopharyngeus and above longitudinal muscle layer of the esophagus
Killian– Jamieson Diverticulum Killian–Jamieson area
 
Laterally between the oblique and transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus
at its attachment to the cricoid cartilage

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Modified Prague’s maneuver is shown in the image. It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Other options:

Lovset’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

 

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Pinard’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the first-trimester ultrasound?

choices.text: A gestational sac can first be seen 4 weeks after LMP
Accuracy of USG dating decreases after the 1st trimester
Yolk sac is the first sign of pregnancy on USG
A normal gestational sac implants in the midline of the endometrial cavity

questions.solution:
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound is the highest in the first trimester and decreases afterwards.

Option A: Gestational sac is reliably seen at 5 weeks of gestation on transvaginal sonography(TVS).

Option C: The first sign of pregnancy seen on sonography is the gestational sac. Visualisation of the yolk sac within the gestational sac confirms an intrauterine location for pregnancy. 

Option D: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, whereas a pseudosac is seen in the midline of the endometrial cavity.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with congestive cardiac failure develops sudden onset skin rashes, tongue swelling, and stridor. He had taken a newly prescribed tablet today morning. Which medication is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of drug-induced angioedema. The drug most likely to have caused this is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor like captopril. 

ACE inhibitors can cause angioedema in a small group which presents as swelling of the throat, mouth, tongue, and glottis. It is usually self-limiting once the drug is discontinued. Glucocorticoids, antihistamines, or epinephrine can be given if required. 

Other adverse effects include hypotension, dry cough, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure.  A rarer complication is visceral angioedema marked by vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It is a known teratogen and needs to be replaced with other drugs during pregnancy/ birth control measures should be advised.

These drugs are inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system and are commonly used in hypertension, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and acute myocardial infarction. 

Other options:

Option A: Propranolol is a nonselective beta-receptor antagonist. Side effects include bronchospasm, depression, and insomnia. It is not recommended for diabetics as it can mask hypoglycemic symptoms.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic can cause hypotension, hypokalemia, and hyponatremia.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist which can cause dry mouth, sedation, and sexual dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of various types of Angioedema

Characteristic Features of Various Types of Angioedema

C1q Level

Inherited defect in the gene for C1-esterase inhibitor. Autosomal dominant: patients have one normal, one abnormal gene

Type I

Recurrent episodic angioedema and abdominal attacks without urticaria. Onset in childhood or young adulthood. 75% have family history. Note that attacks may be oestrogen dependent in this group as well as the Type III form.

Usually LOW

NORMAL

Type II

Usually LOW

NORMAL or HIGH

Type III

Family history present in most cases, onset after childhood. Female patients predominate and attacks often appear to be estrogen-dependent.

NORMAL

Acquired Angioedema (AAE)

Condition not inherited but due to other underlying disease. C1-esterase inhibitor is low due to consumption

Type I

Onset age variable; symptoms same as HAE. No family history, may be associated with underlying lymphoproliferative disease.

 

Usually LOW

LOW

Usually LOW, May be NORMAL

Type II

Onset at variable age; symptoms indistinguishable from HAE. No family history, often associated with an autoantibody that binds to C1-INH.

NORMAL

Drug-induced Angioedema

Angioedema occurs through allergic mechanism and does not involve C1-INH.

ACE Inhibitors

Pseudoallergic (NSAID) or non-allergic (ACE) inhibitors Angioedema may start at first use. Acute onset of well-demarcated subcutaneous non-pitting edema of the face or hands

NORMAL

Angioedema is accompanied by urticaria. Does not usually involve C1-INH.

Allergic AE

Exposure to food, venom, latex, drug, or environmental allergen. May include anaphylaxis

May be LOW or NORMAL

NORMAL

 

NORMAL OR LOW

Long-lasting urticaria with tenderness. Vascular Damage. With Hypocomplementemic Urticarial Vasculitis, the CH5O is usually LOW and so are classical pathway components.

Frequently chronic and relapsing, often occurs with urticarial. Consider test for chronic urticarial (CD203c)

NORMAL

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension was diagnosed with drug-resistant pulmonary TB. One week after starting ATT he presented to the casualty following an episode of syncope. ECG showed a corrected QT interval of 477ms, which is shown below. Which drug used in his anti-tubercular therapy is responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with a corrected QT (QTc) interval of 477ms is suggestive of QTc prolongation which is an adverse effect associated with bedaquiline.

In the ECG QTc (corrected QT interval= QT/√RR) is 477ms. Normal QTc is about 440ms. Values of more than 440ms in males and 460ms in females are considered to be prolonged. QTc prolongation usually presents as syncope or cardiac arrest.

Although QT prolongation can cause Torsades de pointes, no cases have been reported with bedaquiline. A 5-fold higher rate of death has been reported in patients on bedaquiline versus those on placebo. Therefore, the World Health Organization (WHO) advises caution when administering this medication. Bedaquiline is contraindicated in the age group of <18 years.

questions.text:
The results of semen analysis of a young male have been given below. What is the diagnosis?
5 million/ml concentration, 50% motility, 4% normal morphology
questions.solution:
The given scenario of decreased sperm concentration with normal range of motility and morphology points to the diagnosis of oligospermia.

Oligospermia is defined as sperm concentration of <15 million/ml.
It is further subdivided into mild-moderate oligospermia when the concentration is 10-15 million sperms /ml & severe oligospermia when the concentration is <5 million sperms/ml.

Teratozoospermia or teratospermia (option B) is defined as Increased proportion of morphologically abnormal sperms.

Asthenozoospermia or asthenospermia (option C) is used to define sperms with diminished motility.

Term  definition
azoospermia Semen with absent sperms
aspermia Both semen and sperms are absent
leukocytospermia Increased WBC count in the semen
necrospermia Nonviable sperms

 

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: A 21-year-old male comes to the OPD with a peculiar complaint of feeling a sense of unfamiliarity with a familiar person/situation followed often by a brief period of amnesia. Further workup reveals he has temporal lobe epilepsy. The peculiar presenting complaint is known as:
questions.solution:
A sense of unfamiliarity with a familiar situation is known as Jamais Vu whereas the sense of familiarity with an unfamiliar situation is known as Déjà vu. Jamais entendu is a sense of unfamiliarity when hearing something familiar

 Jamais vu and deja vu are associated with pre ictal symptoms that may be seen in those with temporal lobe epilepsy/ complex partial seizures. 

 

  • Formication is a false sense of insects crawling on one's skin. It is also known as cocaine bugs.

questions.text: The two nitrogen atoms in urea are derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The two nitrogen atoms in urea are derived from ammonia and aspartate.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 4-month-old male infant developed otitis media for which he was given a course of cotrimoxazole. A few days later, he developed fever, irritability, and skin tenderness followed by extensive peeling of the skin. There were no mucosal lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The infant presents with an infection focus (otitis media) that is followed by generalized peeling of the skin and toxic state of the baby without any mucosal involvement which is suggestive of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

questions.text: A microbiologist is examining the slide shown in the following image under the microscope. Which of the following is false regarding this?

choices.text: 'B' is used for determining the species
'A' is air dried and stained with a Romanowsky stains
For 'B' to be considered negative, at least 200 oil immersion fields should be examined

questions.solution:
In the given image 'A' is a thin smear and 'B' is a thick smear for the diagnosis of malaria. The thin smear is used for determining the species, not the thick smear.

The two types of smears prepared from the peripheral blood are:

  • Thin smear– It consists of a single layer of RBCs. It is used for detecting the parasites and determining the species. They are air-dried and stained with Romanowsky stains (Leishman, Giemsa etc).
  • Thick smear– It consists of three drops of blood. It is more sensitive and suitable for the rapid detection of malarial parasites. Species identification is difficult. 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a thick film is declared negative.

The image below shows the thin and thick smears.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is the best agent for the long-term treatment of chronic gout in a 50-year-old patient?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is the best agent for the long-term treatment of chronic or recurrent gout.

Hypouricemic drugs that can be used for definitive treatment of chronic gout include:

  • Xanthine oxidase inhibitors- allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Uricosuric agents- probenecid, lesinurad
  • Recombinant uricases- rasburicase and pegloticase

questions.text:
Under the ESI Act, the covered employees contribution to the fund from the daily wages is:

ESI - Employees State Insurance
questions.solution:
The ESI is a self-financing insurance scheme in which the covered employees contribute 0.75% of the wages, whereas, the employers contribute 3.25% of the wages, payable to their employees.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: What do all of the following together represent? “The ability to lead a long and healthy life; the ability to acquire knowledge; and the ability to achieve a decent standard of living”.
questions.solution:
Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as “a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development: To lead a long and healthy life, measured by life expectancy at birth; the ability to acquire knowledge, measured by mean years of schooling; and the ability to achieve a decent standard of living, measured by gross national income per capita”.

Other options:

  • Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI): It consolidates three indicators which include “infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy”.
  • Human Poverty Index (HPI): Measures deprivation in basic dimensions of human development.
  • GNI Index: Gross National Income Index, is a component of HDI.

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: Which of the following patients do not fall under the Pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC)?

choices.text: Patient with an age of 54 years
Patient presenting with a heart rate of 80 bpm
Postmenopausal female not under estrogen therapy
Patient with no history of surgery requiring hospitalisation within the last 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Patients with an age <50 years are included in PERC, not those aged >50 years.

Pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC) lists out certain factors. For patients with a Modified Wells Score ≤ 4, all of these criteria need to be met to exclude the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE), following off anticoagulation, and search for alternative diagnoses.

  • Age < 50 years
  • Heart rate < 100 bpm
  • Oxyhemoglobin saturation on room air ≥ 95%
  • No prior history of venous thromboembolism
  • No recent (within 4 weeks) trauma or surgery requiring hospitalization
  • No presenting hemoptysis
  • No estrogen therapy
  • No unilateral leg swelling

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease is being taken up for cholecystectomy. Which anesthetic agent would be ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent that is ideal for a patient with liver disease is sevoflurane.

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent (has a rapid recovery profile and is not irritating to airways). 

The hepatic effects of volatile anesthetics are caused by alterations in liver perfusion. Hepatic arterial buffer response (HABR) is an autoregulatory mechanism of hepatic blood flow. When portal blood flow decreases due to decreased cardiac output or hypovolemia, the hepatic arterial blood flow increases in order to maintain total hepatic blood flow. This response is best preserved with sevoflurane and isoflurane. Thus, sevoflurane is not known to cause hepatotoxicity. 

Other options:

Option B: Halothane is a volatile anesthetic that has been used for maintenance but it can cause fulminant hepatic necrosis known as halothane hepatitis. 

Option C: Midazolam is an intravenous anesthetic. Its elimination is reduced in liver disease leading to an increased sedating effect.

Option D: Dexmedetomidine is also an intravenous anesthetic that has reduced elimination in patients with liver dysfunction.

 

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane 
Most epileptogenic   Enflurane
Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text: Given below is the histological section of the cornea. Identify the structures marked X and Y in the image.
questions.solution:
The structures marked X and Y are the endothelium and Bowman's membrane, respectively.

The human cornea has five layers. From the anterior to posterior, the layers of the human cornea are as follows:

  1. Corneal epithelium - It is the outermost layer made up of non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. It is continuous with the conjunctival epithelium.
  2. Bowman's layer - The anterior-limiting lamina lies behind the corneal epithelium. It contains a dense mass of collagen (mainly type I collagen fibrils) set in a matrix similar to that of the substantia propria.
  3. Corneal stroma (also substantia propria) - It is a thick, transparent middle layer, consisting of regularly arranged collagen fibers along with sparsely distributed interconnected keratocytes.
  4. Descemet's membrane - It is a thin acellular layer that serves as the modified basement membrane of the corneal endothelium, from which the cells are derived. This layer is composed mainly of collagen type IV fibrils.
  5. Corneal endothelium - The endothelium covers the posterior surface of the cornea and consists of a single layer of squamous cells.

The sixth layer called Dua’s layer or pre-Descemet’s layer has been recently discovered, located between the stroma and the Descemet’s membrane.

questions.text: The POCSO Act is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act is related to child sexual abuse.

POCSO Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines different forms of sexual abuse, including penetrative and non-penetrative assault, as well as sexual harassment and pornography.

The Act deems a sexual assault to be "aggravated" under certain circumstances, such as when the abused child is mentally ill or when the abuse is committed by a person in a position of trust or authority vis-à-vis the child, like a family member, police officer, teacher, or doctor.

People who traffic children for sexual purposes are also punishable under the provisions relating to abetment in the Act. The Act prescribes stringent punishment graded as per the gravity of the offence, with a maximum term of rigorous imprisonment for life and a fine.

questions.text:
Match the images shown with the refractive errors they represent.
Image Refractive error
1 a. Mixed astigmatism
2 b. Simple myopic astigmatism
3 c. Compound myopic astigmatism
4 d. Simple hypermetropic astigmatism
  e. Compound hypermetropic astigmatism
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1 - d, 2 - b, 3 - c, 4 - a. 

Image Refractive error
1 d. Simple hypermetropic astigmatism
2 b. Simple myopic astigmatism
3 c. Compound myopic astigmatism
4 a. Mixed astigmatism

Astigmatism is a refractive error in which the rays of light entering the eye are refracted differently in different meridia of the eye. Meridia of the eye correspond to the lines of longitude on a globe. There are two types of astigmatism - regular and irregular.

In regular astigmatism, refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. Thus, two principal meridia are present. The rays of light from infinity form two focal points due to the difference in curvature of the two principal meridia. Based on the relation of the two focal points to the retina, regular astigmatism has the following types:

  1. Simple astigmatism: One focal point lies on the retina. In simple myopic type, the second focal point lies in front of the retina while in simple hypermetropic type, the second focal point lies behind the retina.
  2. Compound astigmatism: In compound hypermetropic type, both focal points lie behind the retina. In compound myopic type, both focal points lie in front of the retina. 
  3. Mixed astigmatism: One focal point lies in front of while the second focal point lies behind the retina.

questions.text: False statement about the type of study depicted in below given image is:
questions.solution:
Incidence cannot be calculated from case control studies and can be done from longitudinal studies.

Option a: Attrition refers to loss of follow up. Since this is a backward looking study i.e. proceeds from effect to cause, follow up is not done and hence attrition is absent.

Option b: Case control study is suitable for rare diseases.

Option d: It is less time consuming since long term follow up is not needed.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: Which of  the following is a tool used in gene editing:
questions.solution:
Guide RNAs called CRISPRs help to selectively alter or correct DNA sequences.

CRISPR is Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats

  • CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material.
  • CRISPRs are transcribed into an RNA sequence that directs the Cas9 to a sequence leading to its cleavage.
  • Gene editing uses an artificial guide RNA that binds Cas9 and is complementary to a DNA sequence of interest and Cas9 induces the break of double-stranded DNA.

One of the first successful diseases used on experimental basis is Sickle Cell Anemia.

Other gene editing tools are:

  • Zinc-finger nucleases (ZNFs)
  • Transcription-Activator Like Effector Nucleases (TALEN)
  • Meganucleases

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna "for the development of the CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: Motor supply to muscle spindle is _______
questions.solution:
Motor supply to muscle spindle is γ

Muscle spindles have a motor nerve supply of their own.These nerves belong to Erlanger and Gasser’s Aɣ group. They are just 3–6 μ in diameter (hence called small motor nerve system/ɣ efferents of Leksell) and go exclusively to muscle spindles. 

Note:

  • Motor innervation of muscle spindle is by gamma efferents 
  • Motor innervation of extrafusal fibers is by alpha motor neurons

Nuclear bag muscle fibers: 1–3 per muscle spindle.

Nuclear chain muscle fibers: 3–9 per muscle spindle.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of difficulty in breathing. He has a history of road traffic accident 1 year back during which he received prolonged intubation for respiratory support. The flow-volume loop of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and the flow volume loop point toward the diagnosis of tracheal stenosis and the history of prolonged intubation is a risk factor for tracheal stenosis. The graph depicts air flow limited during both inspiration and expiration leading to flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is seen in fixed obstruction of the central or upper airway. 

 

A normal flow-volume loop begins on the X-axis (Volume axis): at the start of the test, both flow and volume are equal to zero. After the starting point, the curve rapidly mounts to a peak: Peak expiratory flow (PEF).

Then, the PEF the curve descends (=the flow decreases) as more air is expired. A normal, non-pathological F/V loop will descend in a straight or a convex line from the top (PEF) to the bottom (FVC).

The forced inspiration that follows the forced expiration has roughly the same morphology, but the PIF (Peak Inspiratory Flow) is not as distinct as PEF.

Classification of the lung pathologies based on this is - 

 

Other options - 

Option A: In COPD, the flow-volume loop shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called the "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern. 

 

Option B: In vocal cord paralysis, the flow-volume loop shows airflow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is an example of nonfixed variable extrathoracic obstruction. 

 

Option D: Obstructive sleep apnea shows a sawtooth pattern of the loop consisting of small, rapid oscillations inflow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson's disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumors of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, upper airway burns, etc

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI image given above is T1 weighted.

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white whereas In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark.

FLAIR: Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. So, CSF is dark, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. The image is given below.

Short-tau inversion recovery (STIR) is an inversion-recovery technique that nulls fat. So, fat is black. It is done to detect bone marrow edema. The image is shown below.

questions.text: Galectin 10 forms:
questions.solution:
Galectin 10, is an eosinophilic protein that forms needle-like Charcot Leyden crystals, seen in bronchial asthma.

Other options:

  • Curschmann spirals are microscopic spiral shaped mucous plugs seen in asthmatics.
  • Creola Bodies are clusters of ciliated columnar cells that slough off from the Bronchial mucosa of a patient with asthma.
  • Schauman Bodies are large basophilic concentric calcifications formed within the cytoplasm of giant cells.

questions.text: A 22 year old male who is a known HIV patient presents with the complaints of anorexia, nausea and watery diarrhoea and abdominal pain for the past two weeks. Given is the histology image of the patient’s jejunum. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above given image shows the histology of jejunum with basophilic spherical structures attached to microvillus surface of epithelium which is seen in Cryptosporidium hominis.

The organism is acquired by fecal–oral transmission of oocysts from either human sources (primarily) or from animal sources.

The oocysts excyst in the small intestine, where the trophozoites attach to the gut wall. Invasion does not occur. The jejunum is the site most heavily infested.  

The disease in immunocompromised patients presents primarily as a watery, nonbloody diarrhea causing large fluid loss. Symptoms persist for long periods in immunocompromised patients, whereas they are self-limited in immunocompetent patients.

Other options:

A) Isospora belli can also cause similar symptoms in immunocompromised patients, but histology shows presence of schizonts and gametocytes within the epithelial cells of the large intestine with villous atrophy and inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. (Image below)

Note : In cryptosporidiosis, it is restricted to the apical region of the epithelial cells.

C) Giardia lamblia: Organisms are teardrop (pear) shaped with paired nuclei in lumen between villi that just adheres to the duodenal epithelium or free lying in the mucosa and never invades.

D) Entamoeba histolytica most commonly affects colon rather than small intestine. Organism burrow into lamina propria and cause tissue necrosis with relatively little inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiency most commonly causes the disease shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a child with albinism and is due to a deficiency of copper-containing enzyme tyrosinase causing a defect in melanin production. The affected child has milky white hair and milky white skin.

In untreated phenylketonuria, the baby looks normal at birth, with a skin and hair color lighter than other members of the family. Later, the child has blonde hair, skin with a light complexion, and blue irides. Manifestations are not so severe as in OCA. The image shows an infant with white hair, so albinism is the best choice.

Note - Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Tyrosine is first hydroxylated to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase. This enzyme is abundant in the central nervous system, the sympathetic ganglia, and the adrenal medulla.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of the kidney?
questions.solution:
The ascending thick limb of the loop of Henle is called the diluting segment.

In the ascending limb, there is the movement of Na+ and Cl– out of the tubular lumen, and the tubular fluid becomes more dilute.

When the fluid reaches the top of the ascending limb, it becomes hypotonic to plasma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below?

choices.text: C is more potent than A
B is more potent than A

questions.solution:
In the above image, drug B is a competitive antagonist.

In competitive antagonism, the DRC is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the Competitive antagonist while drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, the potency is drug A > drug C > drug B.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is drug A = drug B > drug C.

questions.text: As a part of the iodine deficiency control programme, you advocate the usage of iodized salt in hilly areas. What is this type of prevention an example of?
questions.solution:
The usage of iodized salt in iodine-deficient areas like in hilly regions is an example of primary prevention as it provides specific protection.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed every year on 21st October to raise awareness about the fair use of iodine, to highlight the factors that lead to iodine deficiency and its consequences. Iodine deficiency disorders are the world’s most prevalent yet easily preventable disorders.

questions.text: The ring shown in the image below is a ______________
questions.solution:
NuvaRing is a hormonal contraceptive that releases ethinyl estradiol and etonogestrel once inserted into the vagina. The hormones are absorbed through the vaginal epithelium.

The ring is inserted within 5 days of onset of menses and is removed after 3 weeks to allow withdrawal bleeding. After removal, a new ring can be inserted in a week.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting step for hepatic bilirubin metabolism?

choices.text: Secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile

questions.solution:
The secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile is the rate-limiting step for hepatic bilirubin metabolism.

The secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile occurs by an active transport mechanism, which involves multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP-2), also called multispecific organic anion transporter (MOAT). It is located in the plasma membrane of the bile canaliculi.

questions.text: Iliotibial tract receives the insertion of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The iliotibial tract receives the insertion of tensor fasciae latae.

The iliotibial tract is the modification of the deep fascia of the thigh. The proximal end gives attachment to the tensor fascia lata and gluteus maximus. The distal end is attached to Gerdy’s tubercle present on the lateral condyle of the tibia.

questions.text: Identify the graph given below.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a frequency polygon.

Note:

A line graph depicts a time-trend and has time as the x-axis. In the given graph above, the x-axis is the value of Hb concentration.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with angina. Coronary angiography revealed a block in the right coronary artery. Blood supply through which of the following arteries would not be affected?
questions.solution:
The circumflex artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right coronary artery. Hence, blood supply through the circumflex artery won't be affected.

The branches of the right coronary artery are:

  • Right conal artery - first branch of the right coronary artery
  • Artery of the SA node 
  • Acute right marginal artery 
  • Posterior interventricular artery (in 65% population)
  • Atrial and anterior and posterior ventricular branches

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency department with a fever and persistent cough. On examination, chest retractions and tachypnea were noted and expiratory wheezes were heard over both lungs. The culture of the nasopharyngeal swab showed characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Which of the following is most likely to have caused this infection?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture, along with the culture showing characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation, is characteristic of bronchiolitis, which is most likely to be caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

RSV is responsible for more than half of the cases of bronchiolitis in infants less than 1 year of age. Viral transmission is by close contact, droplet transmission, and through contaminated fingers and fomites.

The disease may begin as febrile illness, with cough and wheezing. RSV causes a broad range of respiratory illnesses. Outbreaks are commonly seen in pediatric wards, nurseries, and daycare centers. RSV also causes otitis media in children. 

Samples are collected by nasopharyngeal swabs and nasal washings. They are inoculated in cell culture (HeLa or Hep-2) immediately after collection. In cultured cells, RSV shows characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Cytopathic effects usually appear after 10 days of culture.   

The image given below shows giant cells and syncytial formation seen in RSV infection.

Continuous administration of ribavirin is found beneficial for hospitalized patients.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinovirus attaches to receptors on nasal ciliated epithelial cells, enters and replicates within them, spreading to other cells and causing local inflammation and the common cold.

Option B: Adenovirus types 3 and 7 cause pneumonia in adults. In infants and young children, type 7 causes serious and fatal pneumonia.

Option C: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) causes cytomegalic inclusion disease that occurs in infants born to mothers who develop primary CMV infection during pregnancy.

questions.text: While working at a WHO outreach post in Africa, you conduct an educational program about the Zika virus. What family does this virus belong to?
questions.solution:
Zika virus belongs to the family Flaviviridae.

According to the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV), Zika virus is classified as follows:

  • Family: Flaviviridae
  • Genus: Flavivirus
  • Species: Zika virus

Zika virus is an RNA virus that is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito bite and by sexual contact. Human infections are generally benign and can be misdiagnosed as dengue or influenza. In severe cases, it is associated with Guillain-Barré syndrome or fetal microcephaly.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
The image shows aniridia (irideremia) or absent iris. It can be either congenital or acquired due to trauma. 

Congenital aniridia may be sporadic or inherited. Inherited aniridia may occur as an isolated defect (autosomal dominant PAX6 mutations) or in association with the following systemic and ocular defects.

Systemic associations:

WAGR syndrome

  • Wilms’ tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genitourinary abnormalities
  • Mental Retardation

Associated Ocular defects:

  • Albinism
  • Glaucoma
  • Keratoconus
  • Cataract
  • Ectopia lentis
  • Optic nerve hypoplasia

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the following would you advise him to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has a low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon, candies, and syrupy foods.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has undergone a total thyroidectomy procedure and has been shifted to the post-op ward. 2 hours later she develops stridor and dyspnea, but her voice is normal. Which of the following vocal cord lesions is the most likely cause for her condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture of stridor and dyspnea with a normal voice is most likely due to bilateral abductor paralysis (B/L RLN injury). It is the most dangerous vocal cord lesion.

All the other options will have an abnormality in the voice. Normal voice is seen only in B/L RLN injury.  

In bilateral abductor paralysis,

  • Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing dyspnea and stridor. This may lead to death if untreated.
  • The voice is good.
  • Dyspnea and stridor become worse on exertion or during an attack of acute laryngitis.

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies
