questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the presentation of renal cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Flank pain is the most common presentation
It is more commonly associated with left sided varicoceles
It may be associated with pulsatile bony metastasis
Palpable abdominal mass is part of the classic triad seen in RCC

questions.solution:
The most common presentation in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is gross hematuria.

The classic triad (seen in <10% of cases) includes :

  • Gross hematuria 
  • Flank pain 
  • Palpable abdominal mass 

Rapidly developing varicoceles can be seen in patients with RCC. Varicocele is usually seen on the left side, as the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein at a sharp angle. On the right side, the gonadal vein opens into the much larger IVC.

Patients may also present with paraneoplastic syndromes. RCC can give rise to pulsatile bony metastases.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is commonly used for treating community-acquired pneumonia in OPD?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin is the drug of choice for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in an OPD setup.

Outpatient management of CAP: 

1. For previously healthy patients who have not taken antibiotics within the past 3 months:

  • A macrolide – Azithromycin, 500 mg orally as a first dose and then 250 mg orally daily for 4 days, or 500 mg orally daily for 3 days, or
  • Clarithromycin, 500 mg orally twice a day; or
  • Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day

2. For patients with such comorbid medical conditions as chronic heart, lung, liver, or kidney disease, diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, malignancy, asplenia, immunosuppressant conditions or use of immunosuppressive drugs or use of antibiotics within the previous 3 months:

  • A respiratory fluoroquinolone (moxifloxacin, 400 mg orally daily; gemifloxacin, 320 mg orally daily; levofloxacin, 750 mg orally daily) or
  • A macrolide (as above) plus a beta-lactam (amoxicillin, 1 g orally three times a day; amoxicillin-clavulanate, 2 g orally twice a day; cefuroxime, 500 mg orally twice a day).

3. In regions with a high rate (> 25%) of infection with high level (MIC ≥ 16 mcg/mL) macrolide-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae, consider the use of alternative agents listed in (2) for patients with comorbidities.

Other options: Vancomycin, Ceftriaxone, and Streptomycin are administered parenterally, and hence, not appropriate for outpatient management.

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: A young woman presented with the following lesion on her vulva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata that shows cauliflower-like masses of tissue on and around the female anogenital region. 

Condyloma acuminatum is an epidermal manifestation of the human papillomavirus (HPV). 

HPV is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells of the epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. However, anogenital HPV infection is almost always acquired through sexual contact. 

Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load.

Option B: The image given below shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a characteristic dimple at the centre. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum caused by the pox virus.

Option C: The image given below shows firm papules with a rough horny surface. These are seen in verruca vulgaris caused by the human papillomavirus type 2.

Option D: The image given below shows condyloma lata which is the characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is referred to your center for management of severe hyperglycemia. During examination, you note that the patient has enlarged feet, coarse facial features and prognathism. You suspect acromegaly. Which of the following tests can you use as a screening method for this condition?

choices.text: Oral glucose challenge test with GH level
Insulin-like growth factor-1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3) level

questions.solution:
The best screening test for acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) level.

Other options:

Options A and B: Oral glucose challenge test with growth hormone (GH) levels is used for further confirmation of the diagnosis. Increased insulin-like growth factor-1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3) levels can also be seen in patients with acromegaly. But they are not typically used as initial screening methods.

Option D: IGF-1 levels are more reliable than random GH levels because GH secretion is pulsatile. IGF-1 levels reflect long-term exposure to GH and provide a more stable indicator of excessive GH production.

Acromegaly is characterized by excessive GH secretion, usually caused by a somatotrope adenoma in the pituitary gland. It can also be due to ectopic GH secretion or hypothalamic tumors.

The clinical presentation of acromegaly includes frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, coarse facial features, mandibular prognathism, widened space between lower incisors and other manifestations such as soft tissue swelling, deepening voice, carpal tunnel syndrome, arthropathy, and acanthosis nigricans.

It can also lead to cardiovascular complications (cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, and hypertension), obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, an increased risk of colon polyps, and colonic malignancy. 

The primary treatment for acromegaly is surgical resection of GH-secreting adenomas. Somatostatin receptor ligands like octreotide and lanreotide, which suppress GH and IGF-1 levels, are used as adjuvant treatment or when surgery is not possible or unsuccessful. Radiation therapy may be considered for patients who cannot tolerate or do not respond to medical therapy. Other treatment options include GH receptor antagonists like pegvisomant and dopamine agonists like cabergoline.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: The following image shows an ovarian follicle. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Cells of the layer marked ‘A’ is actively stimulated by FSH
Cells of the layer marked ‘A’ synthesise androgens from the cholestrol
Cells of the layer marked ‘B’ do not have receptor for LH
Cells of the layer marked ‘B’ lack the enzyme aromatase

questions.solution:
The region marked ‘A’ is theca interna and the region marked ‘B’ is granulosa cell layer. Synthesis of estrogen is mainly due to the interaction between granulosa cells and theca cells. In an overview, the theca interna cells synthesise progesterone and androgens from the cholestrol which subsequently are coverted to estrogens by the granulosa cells.

Salient features of theca interna cells:

  • The theca interna cells are actively stimulated by LH (Luetinising hormone).
  • They are involved in the synthesis of progestogens and androgens.
  • Estrogens are not formed in theca cells as they lack the enzyme aromatase.

Salient features of granulosa cells:

  • The granulosa cells have receptors for both LH and FSH.
  • They convert the androgens provided by  the theca cells to estrogens with the help of an enzyme aromatase.
  • The following image shows interaction between the theca cell and granulosa cell in the synthesis of estrogen:

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. It allows for the electrodes to be in close proximity to the ganglion cells and their dendrites which are located in the modiolus and bony spiral lamina of the cochlea. 

A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the auditory nerve. Prerequisites include an intact cochlear nerve and higher auditory pathway.

In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle. It is used when the cochlear nerve is not intact.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that passes through the marked foramen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is superior orbital fissure through which abducent nerve passes through.

The superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring.

Compartments Contents
Superolateral compartments Lacrimal, frontal and trochlear nerve (LFT), Superior ophthalmic vein
Intermediate compartment Superior and inferior division of oculomotor, Nasociliary nerve, Abducent nerve
Inferomedial compartment Inferior ophthalmic vein

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery

  • Inferior petrosal sinus

  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)

  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
ε-Aminocaproic acid can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

It is a lysine analog that binds competitively to plasminogen, blocking plasminogen from binding to fibrin and the subsequent conversion to plasmin. This activity subsequently results in the inhibition of fibrinolysis.

It should not be given unless hemorrhage is life-threatening because it inhibits intrinsic fibrinolytic activity and can precipitate DIC. Fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate may also be used to replenish fibrin and clotting factors.

questions.text: The anomaly shown in the image given below is mostly associated with ____________
questions.solution:
The anomaly shown in the image is caudal regression which is mostly associated with maternal diabetes.

It is a rare anomaly. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and, to a lesser degree, the lumbar vertebrae, and occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infant of a diabetic mother than in other infants.

questions.text: Auditory information is relayed through ______ thalamic nucleus.
questions.solution:
The medial geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys auditory information from the brainstem to the primary auditory cortex.

Lateral geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys visual information.

Related Pearl: Central Auditory Pathway

E.Coli - MA (mnemonic)

Eighth nerve 

Cochlear nuclei 

Olivary complex 

Lateral lemniscus 

Inferior colliculus 

Medial geniculate body 

Auditory cortex

Most of the primary auditory cortex is in the temporal lobe, but the association cortices extend over much of the insular lobe and even onto the lateral portion of the parietal lobe.

questions.text: All the tests are used for seminal stains except ___________
questions.solution:
Spectroscopic test is used to detect blood stain (not seminal stain). Florence test, Barberio test and creatine phosphokinase test are used to detect seminal stain.

Forensic tests for detection of stains:

 

Seminal stains Blood stains
  • Barberio test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect PSA (Prostate Specific Antigen)
  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

 

 

  • Florence test detects choline (secreted by seminal vesicles). Florence solution consists of potassium iodide, iodine and water.
  • Barberio’s test detects spermin (secreted by prostate) and uses aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid.
  • Acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia.
  • The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

questions.text: Banana sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The banana sign is seen in spina bifida.
  • Spina bifida is a type of open neural tube defect and is commonly associated with hydrocephalus and Arnold-Chiari II malformation.

Spina bifida is characterised by:

  • A cleft in the vertebral column
  • With a corresponding defect in the skin so that the meninges and spinal cord are exposed.

Myelomeningocele (spina bifida) is the most common open neural tube disorder.

Banana sign:

  • It seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari II is the banana sign.There is herniation of the brainstem and cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, with the cerebellum surrounding the brainstem with a curved shape of a banana.

In the image given below, the cerebellum (arrows)  is stretched around the brainstem (B) with effacement of the cisterna magna.

The lemon sign is related to changes in the configuration of the fetal frontal bone that loses convexity, becoming concave or linear at ultrasonography and can be found during the first six months of gestation.

Axial US image of an 18-week old foetus with spina bifida, at the level of Choroid plexus showing the characteristic lemon sign.

questions.text: In which procedure is the instrument shown in the image most commonly used?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is the Quincke Needle used in spinal anesthesia. The Quincke needle is a cutting needle with end injection.

Spinal needles are long thin needles that are classified based on their tip into: 

  • Cutting needles: Quincke-Babcock, Pitkin
  • Pencil tip needles: Whitacre and Sprotte

 

This is the image of a Tuohy needle that is used to provide epidural anesthesia. It can be recognised by its curved (Huber) tip and the markings made at 1 cm interval along it's length.

The above image shows a Combined Spinal Epidural needle. It consists of a spinal needle passed through the epidural needle.

questions.text: You are evaluating a woman with unilateral facial weakness. However, you notice forehead wrinkling is intact. On examination, which of the following findings would you not expect?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion of the facial nerve in which the emotional response is affected. Patients with UMN lesions of the facial nerve have emotional incontinence i.e. involuntary, uncontrollable laughter, or crying with a paradoxical deficit of facial expression.

Normally cerebellum modulates motor outputs in response to sensory inputs. UMN facial palsy (type of pseudobulbar palsy) is associated with disruption of cortico-ponto-cerebellar pathways leading to loss of cerebellar modulation resulting in:

  • Emotional dysmetria (difficulty in fine-tuning emotional responses)
  • Emotional disinhibition (excessive emotional output)

Difference between UMN and LMN facial palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy Absent Present

questions.text: The Emsley-Fincham test is performed in a patient who complains of blurred vision and seeing colored halos. The patient reports breaking up of the halo into rotating segments. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Breaking up of coloured halos into rotating segments on performing the Emsley-Fincham test with a stenopaeic slit indicates cataract.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling in the buccal cavity. A biopsy of the tissue was done and the histological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows both epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right), which is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is the most common site. The submandibular and minor salivary glands are the less common sites. They present as painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses within the parotid or submandibular areas or in the buccal cavity.

Gross features- The tumors are rounded and well-demarcated. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

Microscopic features consist of:

  • The epithelial elements- They resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • Mesenchymal elements consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

Other options: 

Option A - Oncocytomas arise from the kidneys. They are epithelial neoplasms that are composed of large eosinophilic cells with small, round, benign-appearing nuclei with large nucleoli. 

 

Option B - Ductal papillomas arise from the ductal epithelium of the breast. They have multiple branching fibrovascular cores with epithelial hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia. The following image shows the histological appearance of ductal papilloma. 

 

Option D - Warthin tumors are benign neoplasms of the parotid gland. They appear as round to oval encapsulated masses. Histologically, they have a dense lymphoid stroma with germinal centers, the spaces are narrowed by polypoid projections of lymphoepithelial elements. The upper later has palisading columnar cells and the lower layer has cuboidal to polygonal cells. The following image shows a Warthin tumor. 

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

Type of Salivary gland

Location

Frequency of tumor

Percentage of malignancy

Major

Parotid

Common

10–20%
 

Submandibular

Uncommon

Sublingual

Very rare

questions.text: Triage is done during disaster management to ensure treatment of casualties is done properly. What is true about triage done at the disaster site?

choices.text: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
Most commonly used system is three  color code system

questions.solution:
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority. 

This is because despite paying quite a lot of attention, the benefit is still questionable.

 

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown above is marbling.

The blood in the vessels is hemolyzed, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin becomes prominent about 36–48 hours after death in summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image of the child, shown below, is suggestive of _________
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage.

As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

The temporoparietal convexity is the most common site. The hematoma usually lies beneath a fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone. The underlying brain is displaced but often appears intrinsically normal.

Monitoring an extradural hemorrhage and immediate intervention if necessary is an important step in management since the brain can herniate with increased bleeding that is causing raised ICP.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and painful swelling of the left eye. He is being treated for acute ethmoiditis for 5 days. On examination, the visual acuity in the left eye is 6/12, there is chemosis, axial proptosis, limitation of ocular motility in all directions, and RAPD. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of this patient is orbital cellulitis.

Orbital cellulitis is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children. Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in children.

Orbital cellulitis presents with pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis. Decreased ocular motility and elevated intraocular pressure can be seen. Systemic symptoms include malaise and fever. A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve. With posterior exenteration cavernous sinus thrombosis, subdural empyema, and intracranial abscess develop.

WARNING SIGNS: Dilated pupil, marked ophthalmoplegia, loss of vision, afferent pupillary defect, papilledema, and violaceous lids.

questions.text: In a patient with atrophic rhinitis, what is the main reason for nasal obstruction?
questions.solution:
Nasal obstruction in a patient with atrophic rhinitis is due to excessive crust formation.

Turbinates are atrophied here.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: The device shown in the image cannot be used for _____.

choices.text: A patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment

questions.solution:
Ilizarov fixator cannot be used for a patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment as it would cause direct seeding of tissue.

Uses:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Nonunion
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Arthrodesis by crushing the articular surfaces against each other

It can also be used for preventing the progression of fat embolism syndrome as external fixation is one of the modalities used as a part of damage control surgery.

questions.text: A 54-year-old incapacitated patient admitted under your care has an advance directive regarding his treatment. You believe the advance directive is not in the best interests of the patient and wish to follow a different clinical plan. Which of the following is the most suitable approach?

choices.text: Take consent from the relative/ caretaker whoever is available and proceed
Send an application to mental health board to alter the advance directive
Inform the ethics board of the hospital and proceed as per new plan
Proceed as per patient's advance directive as it is final and binding

questions.solution:
According to the Mental Health Care Act, 2017, the mental health professional who does not wish to follow the directive by the patient can write an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman underwent an emergency LSCS under general anesthesia to deliver a term, healthy infant. Two hours later, she developed sudden tachypnea, cyanosis, and massive pulmonary edema and died despite resuscitative measures. The histopathological picture of her lung is shown below.  What is the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing massive neutrophilic infiltration are suggestive of Mendelson’s syndrome or aspiration pneumonitis.

Mendelson's syndrome is a chemical pneumonitis caused by the aspiration of sterile gastric contents during general anesthesia, especially during pregnancy. The most common cause of maternal mortality associated with general anesthesia is either due to a pulmonary aspiration or a failed endotracheal intubation. 

The risk factors for Mendelson's syndrome include:

  • Gastric volume > 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg)
  • Gastric pH < 2.5

Incidence of aspiration can be reduced by administration of:

  • Non-particulate antacids like sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation
  • H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine 
  • Metoclopramide 1-2 hours prior to induction

Option B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is a type of ILD associated with Masson bodies and plugs of loose connective tissue on histology.

Option C: CMV pneumonia is associated with the owl's eye appearance on histology.

Option D: PCP pneumonia is associated with black-walled cysts on silver staining.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presented to the hospital after a road traffic accident with a fracture of the pelvis. There was urinary retention and blood at the urethral meatus. On digital rectal examination, he had a high-riding prostate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with blood at the tip of the meatus and high-riding prostate on examination is suggestive of rupture of the membranous urethra.

Rupture Membranous urethra Bulbar urethra
Cause Fracture of the pelvis Blow to the perineum (fall-astride injury-straddle injury)
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at urethral meatus
  • Perineal bruising and hematoma
Investigation Retrograde urethrogram  Retrograde urethrogram

In both cases, the initial management should be the insertion of a suprapubic catheter. Passing a catheter blindly per urethra is not advised as this can convert a partial tear into a complete tear. 

However, delayed urethroplasty is the definitive management for complete urethral tear.

questions.text: What is the optimum temperature for storage of RBCs collected in preservatives?
questions.solution:
The optimum temperature for storage of packed RBCs and whole blood collected in preservatives is +2° to +6° C. This temperature maintains the viability of the cells and prevents bacterial contamination.

Blood component  Storage temperature Shelf-life
PRBCs +2° to +6 °C

CPD-21 days

CPD-A-35 days

SAG M-42 days
Platelets +20 to +24 °C 5 days
Fresh frozen plasma -30 °C or lower 1 year
Cryoprecipitate -30 °C or lower 1 year

Related Pearl: Blood components

Component Volume     (1 unit) Content Clinical response, increase in  Storage temperature Shelf-life
Whole blood 450 ml RBCs, platelets, plasma Hb and plasma volume    
Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) 300-350 ml RBCs

Hb by 1 g/dl

Hematocrit by 3%

1° to 6°C

ACD/CPD-21 days, CPD-A-35 days, additive-42 days
Random donor platelets (RDP) 50-70 ml Platelets platelet count by 5000-10,000/µL 20 to 24°C 5 days
Single donor apheretic platelets (SDP*) 200-400 ml Platelets platelet count by 30,000/µL
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) 200-250 ml Coagulation factors, protein C, protein S, anti thrombin coagulation factors by 2% -40 to -50°C 1 year
Cryoprecipitate 10-15 ml fibrinogen, factor VIII, VWF 80 IU Factor VIII -30 °C 1 year

 

*SDP is obtained by collecting multiple units of platelets from a single donor using apheretic technology. 

1 SDP = 6 RDP

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?

ABG - metabolic acidosis

Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL

Blood Urea – 100 mg/dl

Creatinine – 3.4 mg/dl

Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals.
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage. 

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomipezole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

questions.text: The given image shows a newborn brought to the OPD by his mother who has noticed the whitish lesions. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows Milia.

Milia are:

  • Also known as “milk spots”
  • Pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts.
  • Located over the face usually.
  • Resolve spontaneously without scarring.
  • Require no treatment.

Milia is distinct from Miliaria.

Miliaria is a disease of the eccrine sweat gland.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room after he was brutally beaten during a mugging incident. He is unresponsive even to painful stimuli and is apneic; however, he does have a pulse. Which of the following clinical findings would exclude a diagnosis of brain death?
questions.solution:
Constricted pupils would rule out brain death.

Brain death is the irreversible cessation of all cerebral function with the preservation of cardiac activity and maintenance of respiratory and somatic function by artificial means.

In brain death, the pupils are usually midsized or maybe dilated. However, constricted pupils are not seen. 

The diagnosis of brain death should be confirmed with the following clinical findings:

  • Absent brain-originating motor response, including response to pain stimulus above the neck or other brain-originating movements (eg, seizures, decerebrate or decorticate posturing)
  • Unresponsiveness to any stimuli
  • Brainstem damage, as evidenced by dilated or mid-sized pupils without light reaction
  • Absent corneal, gag, and oculovestibular reflexes
  • Absent sucking or rooting reflexes
  • Absent cough with tracheal suctioning
  • Apnea, indicating medullary destruction
  • The heart rate should be invariant and does not accelerate to atropine

questions.text: Which fibre is marked by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the internal capsule, which is a form of projection fiber.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of severe insomnia. She has been feeling ants walking over the skin of her legs, and an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep. The drug of choice for treating this condition would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with insomnia feeling ants walking over her skin along with an irresistible urge to move her legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep is indicative of restless leg syndrome and gabapentin is the first-line choice of treatment for this condition.    

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. Moving the leg or walking alleviates the symptoms. This cycle sometimes continues for hours during the night and can result in profound insomnia. Decreased dopamine receptor expression and mild dopaminergic hypofunction are usually noted in these patients.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route?
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons).  The basic cycles of transmission are:

 (a)Pig → Mosquito  → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which of the following produce estrogen and progesterone in the first two months of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
In the first two months of pregnancy, estrogen and progesterone are produced by the corpus luteum.

It functions maximally during the second month of pregnancy and thereafter contributes relatively little. Estrogen is synthesized in the placenta from the 7th week and progesterone from the 8th week.

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest?
questions.solution:
If the DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, the p53 gene causes arrest of the cell cycle in G1 phase to provide time for DNA repair. In case the DNA damage could not be repaired, p53 triggers apoptosis.
 
In conditions where there is mutation in p53 gene, the cells with damaged DNA continue to replicate and thus may undergo neoplastic transformation.

Related Pearl: Tumor suppressor genes

E-cadherin

Growth inhibition

Chromosome 19

Chromosome 16
NF1 Inhibition of RAS signal transduction and of p21 cell cycle inhibitor Chromosome 17
NF2 Cytoskeletal instability Chromosome 22

APC/Beta-catenin

 Inhibition of signal transduction Chromosome 5
PTEN Pi3 kinase signal transduction Chromosome 10
SMAD2 and SMAD4 TGF- beta signal transduction Chromosome 18

WT1

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels <9.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
In the given population, 5 women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels < 9.5 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean. 
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean. 
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

In a normal distribution, 2 SD from the mean will have 95% of the participants. Therefore, 95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels of 10.5±2*0.5 = 10.5±1 =  9.5-11.5 g/dL.

The remaining 2.5% of women will have Hb >11.5 g/dL and 2.5% of women will have Hb level <9.5 g/dL.

2.5% of 200 = 5. Hence, 5 women will have Hb of <9.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A patient had an injury over his hand while gardening. After a few days, the skin became infected and painful. The culture of the wound on blood agar showed yellow-colored colonies, which showed effervescence when hydrogen peroxide is added to blood-agar as shown below. Which of the following organisms is most likely?
questions.solution:
The characteristic golden yellow coloured colonies on blood agar and catalase-positive reaction suggest the growth of Staphylococcus aureus. The catalase converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, which causes effervescence on the media.

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: The pre-anesthetic evaluation of a 33-year-old male who has been posted for surgery is conducted, and the oral cavity examined is as depicted in the image given below. This would be______________ according to Mallampati classification.
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, fauces, and part of the uvula are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class II.

Mallampati classification: Here the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity is assessed. The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult the intubation.

Mallampati class III and class IV are considered risk factors for difficult ventilation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic dyspepsia underwent upper GI endoscopy. The biopsy findings are shown below. What is the special stain that has been used?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Barrett's esophagus showing intestinal metaplasia. The special stain used here is Alcian blue, which stains the acid mucin present in the goblet cells.
