questions.text: The most probable diagnosis inferred from the given clinical images is?
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive condition where the absorption of zinc is defective by the intestinal epithelial cell. Affected infants respond dramatically to zinc supplementation.

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele’s rule.
questions.solution:
As per Naegele’s rule, the EDD (expected date of delivery) of this woman is October 16, 2017.

Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the LMP (the 1st day of the last menstrual period). Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. 

It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated as follows:

  • For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
  • For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.

Naegele’s rule cannot be followed in IVF pregnancies. Considering the human embryo takes 266 days to develop, EDD is calculated in IVF pregnancies by the following method:

  • Same day as fertilization (day 0): EDD = date of transfer + 266 days 
  • 3 days after fertilization (day 3): EDD = date of transfer + 263 days
  • 5 days after fertilization (day 5): EDD = date of transfer + 261 days

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Bakri balloon. It is used in uterine tamponade in patients with atonic PPH who are unresponsive to medical management.

The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine cavity.

It acts by stimulating uterine contraction and direct hemostatic pressure to the open uterine sinuses (tamponade effect).

The maximum capacity of the balloon is 500mL. It is inflated with normal saline (200-500mL) and can be retained for up to 12 hours. Success rates are high and it can be used to avoid hysterectomy.

Other options: Sengstaken Blakemore tube, condom catheter, and 34F Foley with 60mL balloon are other instruments that can be used for uterine tamponade.

The image below depicts Sengstaken Blakemore tube.

The image below depicts Foley's catheter.

questions.text: A  young patient presents with complaints of cramping abdominal pain and painless bright red bleeding in stools for the past 1 week. External and digital rectal examinations are normal. What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The first step in the workup of suspected lower GI bleed is to rule out the anorectal source of the bleed by digital rectal examination (DRE) and proctoscopy. Proctoscopy is a procedure used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum (up to 10 cm). Biopsy of the suspicious areas can be taken if needed.

Examination of the rectum:

- Visual inspection of the perineum
- Digital examination
- Proctoscopy
- Sigmoidoscopy – rigid and/or flexible

If the anorectal cause of bleeding is ruled out, it is important to eliminate an upper GI source through nasogastric (NG) aspiration or esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). An NG aspirate that contains bile and no blood effectively rules out upper tract bleeding in most patients.

Colonoscopy can be performed next when the anorectal or upper GI cause of bleeding is ruled out or if the extent of the hemorrhoid disease is incongruent with the patient’s symptoms, or if the patient has risk factors for colon cancer, such as a family history.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the OPD with a button like subareolar mass that is painless. The histologic picture that you would commonly expect to find is:

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation surrounding ducts with numerous plasma cell infiltrates
Lobule expansion containing monotonous epithelial cell proliferation
Epithelial hyperplasia of the duct with tapering micropapillae without lobule formation

questions.solution:
Adolescent Male with button-like painless subareolar mass points towards the diagnosis being Gynaecomastia.

Histological features observed are:

  • An increase in dense collagenous connective tissue
  • Epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micropapillae.
  • Lobule formation is almost never observed

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the oculomotor nerve and it does not supply the superior oblique muscle. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text: As evident from the relative sizes, the substances shown in the image are:

choices.text: A - LDL, B - VLDL, C - HDL
A - VLDL, B - HDL, C - LDL
A - HDL, B - VLDL, C - LDL
A - VLDL, B - LDL, C - HDL

questions.solution:
The image shows A - VLDL, B - LDL, C - HDL respectively.

The correct order of relative sizes is VLDL>LDL>HDL.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with pain, numbness, and fatigue of the right arm. Angiography reveals decreased flow through the vessels anastomosing near the surgical neck of the humerus. The pathology is likely to be present in which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The branches of the third part of the axillary artery supply the surgical neck of the humerus. Thrombus in this part will cause decreased supply in its branches - the anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries.

Branches of 3rd part of the axillary artery are:

  • Anterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Posterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Subscapular artery (not involved in the anastomosis)

Fracture of the surgical neck is the commonest site among all proximal humerus fractures due to its inherent weakness. Fracture at this site may cause injury to the posterior circumflex humeral artery and the axillary nerve that accompanies it.

Positional compression of the axillary artery is seen in athletes who are involved with throwing movement, as in baseball players. Repeated movement of the humerus may cause compression of the distal part of the axillary artery. This may lead to thrombosis or aneurysm resulting in arm ischemia.

questions.text: An anxious mother from rural India brings her 2-year-old boy with complaints of uncontrolled jerking of the left side of his body. She says that he has had the 'devil’s stain' over the right side of his face since birth. She claims that the stain has been becoming larger and darker depicting the 'devil's strength increasing over time'. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes unilateral seizure activity with a port-wine stain, suggestive of Sturge–Weber syndrome (SWS), a severe neurocutaneous disorder.

The port-wine stain is a vascular plaque (capillary malformation) over the lateral aspect of the forehead mainly involving the territory of ophthalmic(V1) and maxillary (V2) division of the trigeminal nerve. It presents with ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas and contralateral seizures or hemiparesis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of repeated chest infections with the presence of large amounts of sputum in a non-smoker point to the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. The CT scan showing the signet ring sign is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheeze, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis along with low-grade fever, and weight loss. On CT, Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy can be seen.

The image given below shows cavities in pulmonary tuberculosis:

 

Option C: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on imaging. 

Option D: Patients with bronchial asthma present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. On CT, bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping is seen.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

Related Pearl: Types of Bronchiectasis

Cylindrical/Tubular Saccular/Varicose Cystic
  • Mildest form of bronchiectasis
  • Loss of normal airway tapering
  • Bronchi have a uniform calibre, have parallel walls tram track sign and signet ring sign
  • Further distortion of the airway wall along with more mucous and sputum production
  • Beaded bronchi with interspersed sites of relative narrowing
  • Most severe form of bronchiectasis and least common
  • This form has large air spaces and a honeycombed appearance
  • Air fluid levels present

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient who had undergone cataract surgery previously is noted to have the following finding on ocular examination. What is this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding noted in the image above is Soemmering's ring, which is one of the types of after-cataract.

After-cataract is the most common postoperative complication encountered following cataract surgery. Soemmering's ring is defined as a thick ring of after-cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction.

No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear. If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

The image given below shows different types of after-cataract.

Other options:

Option A: Vossius' ring is a small ring shaped pigment on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule that occurs following blunt trauma.

Option C: Weiss' or Vogt’s ring is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: An unconscious patient of head injury comes in the casualty. On examination there is raised intracranial pressure. Which anesthetic agent is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is contraindicated in raised intracranial pressure.

Ketamine is a direct cardiac-depressant by inhibiting Ca2+ channels, but this is masked by its indirect sympathomimetic action which may cause

Increase in all pressures like ICT, IOP, BP and hence contraindicated in:

  • Raised intracranial pressure/pathology with mass effect/ head injury
  • Hypertension, Ischemic heart disease, arterial aneurysm
  • Open eye injury, glaucoma or vitreoretinal surgery
    • Most potent bronchodilator with intact upper airway reflexes. Hence anaesthesia of choice in asthma (status asthmaticus).
    • Increased BP, CO, HR, cardiac metabolism, oxygen demand
    • Increased cerebral blood flow/ metabolism/ oxygen consumption and seizures.
    • Increases muscle tone and is an arrhythmogenic.
  • Preferred anaesthetic agent in head injury:
    • Thiopentone (Cerebro protective)
    • Propofol
    • Etomidate (protects against circulatory depression)
    • Isoflurane

questions.text: In a patient, following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, sensation over the medial side of the leg was lost. The affected nerve is a branch of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation of the medial side of the leg denotes injury to the saphenous nerve. It is a branch of the posterior division of the femoral nerve.

The saphenous nerve is the largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve.

It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery. It then enters the adductor canal where it crosses anterior to the femoral artery to lie medial to it. It leaves the adductor canal by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella.

It then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the long saphenous vein and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee leg and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

The images given below show the cutaneous innervation of the lower limb.

questions.text: While waiting for corrective open-heart surgery, you decide to manage a case of tet spells medically. Which of the following drugs would worsen the cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Isoprenaline/isoproterenol should be avoided in tet or hypercyanotic spells. It will cause a decrease in total peripheral resistance (TPR) or systemic vascular resistance (SVR). So, more blood leaves the left ventricle leading to the increased right to left shunt. This results in the worsening of right ventricular outflow and causes worsening of cyanosis and the symptoms.

Treatment of hypercyanotic spell involves placing child in knee–chest position (or squatting), and use of:

  • oxygen
  • morphine - sedates the patient
  • sodium bicarbonate - to counteract metabolic acidosis that develops when arterial Po2 <40 mmHg 
  • alpha-agonists (phenylephrine)- vasopressor used in severe cases
  • beta-blockers (propranolol)- improves resting saturation and decreases the frequency of spells.

Drugs that increase SVR, such as IV phenylephrine (alpha-1 agonist) or propranolol (non-selective beta-antagonist/beta-2 block), can improve right ventricular outflow, decrease the right-to-left shunt, and improve the symptoms. This is same principle as squatting.

questions.text: In oxidative phosphorylation, the ATP production and respiratory chain are linked by ____________
questions.solution:
The chemiosmotic theory states that the two processes (respiratory chain and synthesis of ATP) are coupled by a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane.

The proton motive force caused by the electrochemical potential difference drives the mechanism of ATP synthesis.

The chemiosmotic theory was proposed by Peter Mitchell in 1961.

questions.text: You have prescribed oral iron supplements for an anemic young woman. Which of the following foods should she avoid taking along with these supplements?
questions.solution:
Tea contains tannins, which inhibit iron absorption. Hence, it should not be taken with iron supplements. Iron absorption is also reduced by:

  • Calcium supplements and antacids
  • Milk and dairy products
  • Proton pump inhibitors

Grapefruit and kiwi are acid-containing citrus fruits that create an acidic pH and hence, increase iron absorption. 

Broccoli contains ascorbic acid that also enhances iron absorption.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: A 33 Weeks multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, and proteinuria - 3+. The next step of management would be?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 33 weeks pregnant woman with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, and proteinuria 3+ indicates severe preeclampsia. The next step of management would be iv administration of MgSO4 for the prevention of seizures. 

Preeclampsia can be classified as severe if any of the following are present: 

  • BP ≥160/110
  • Headache
  • Visual disturbance
  • Upper abdominal pain
  • Elevated creatinine, oliguria
  • Thrombocytopenia (<1,00,000 cells per mm3)
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Marked elevation in serum transaminases
  • Fetal growth restriction

Dexamethasone (option B) is also given in severe preeclampsia <34 weeks for fetal lung maturity. But the administration of MgSO4 before corticosteroids would be the next best step for the prevention of seizures. 

Immediate delivery (options A and C) is not indicated in this case as the patient doesn't have any contraindication for conservative management. Conservative management is contraindicated in the following cases:

  • Persistent symptoms, refractory to treatment or severe hypertension
  • Eclampsia, pulmonary edema, HELLP syndrome
  • Significant renal dysfunction or coagulopathy
  • Placental abruption
  • Nonreassuring fetal status
  • Fetal demise
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Stroke, myocardial infarction

MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe preeclampsia:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibal) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2g/h IV infusion

Magnesium sulfate is discontinued either 24 hours after delivery or 24 hours after the onset of convulsions (whichever is later).

questions.text: You are posted in the labor room. While inspecting the placenta to rule out any abnormalities, you notice that it appears pale and enlarged. Which of the following infections does the mother most likely have?
questions.solution:
Enlarged and pale placenta is due to infection by syphilis.

Other clinical manifestations and complications include:

  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Stillbirth
  • Non-immune hydrops 
  • Intrauterine growth restriction 
  • Perinatal death.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman working in a chemical industry is not given protective masks and goggles. The employer is liable under
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the employer is liable under the Factories (Amendment) Act, 1987.

The Factories Act, 1948 has prescribed in detail the precautions to be taken for ensuring the safety of the workers. Including protective devices (like goggles) and precautions against dangerous fumes.

The Factories Act was amended in the year 1987. It stipulates pre-employment examination as a pre-placement procedure, and statutory periodic medical examination for a job in hazardous areas.

Other options:

Option A- The Maternity Act, 2017: it enhances the duration of paid maternity leave.

Option B- The Employees State Insurance Act, 1948: It provides for certain cash and medical benefits to industrial employees in case of sickness, maternity, and employment injury.

Option C- Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna, 2005: It provides an unemployment allowance for the employees covered under the ESI Scheme.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Sunita, a 28 year old female was brought to ER following abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, preceded by amenorrhea for 8 weeks. She has a past history ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg and pulse rate of 94 beats/minute, with urine pregnancy test positive. The next step of management would be ______
questions.solution:
In this case scenario, the next step of management would be a transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS)  as she has a high likelihood of ectopic pregnancy.

In any woman of the reproductive age group, with amenorrhoea, positive urine pregnancy test and hemodynamically stable vaginal bleeding, TVUS is the next step of management to rule out abortion or ectopic pregnancy. If the TVUS is non-diagnostic, then serum quantitative beta hCG is evaluated.

In a similar case scenario with unstable vitals, transabdominal scan/FAST may be performed, to assess quickly for intraperitoneal hemorrhage. If positive, it is an ectopic pregnancy until proven otherwise and Laprotomy is performed.

This MCQ has been revised as a whole to reflect the accurate steps of management for a woman with suspected ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given staining technique.
questions.solution:
The organism shown above is the Nocardia species. The above image shows acid-fast staining, where the organisms are shown appear as acid-fast (stained with fuschia) and branching rods or filaments. They are aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections in the immunocompromised.

Options A, B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but do not have branching filaments.

Option C: Actinomyces species is gram-positive but not acid-fast.

questions.text: The CTG shown in the image below may be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows early deceleration which is seen in cases of head compression.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: True statement about the phenomenon seen in the image below:

choices.text: The cells being engulfed is destroyed immediately
A cell engulfs the cell of same type
The cell being engulfed undergo division inside the host cell
The above condition helps in the destruction of dead cells

questions.solution:
The above image showing a cell within a cell is termed as emperipolesis.

Emperipolesis is a condition where living and intact state hematopoietic cells are seen in the cytoplasm of a host cell without any damage. Both of these cells remain viable without any physiological or morphological changes. The cells taken in are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. The host cells may be a megakaryocyte, monocyte, endothelial cell, fibroblast, or malignant cells. The engulfed cell is enclosed in a membrane-bound vacuole in the cytoplasm of the host cell. Internalized cells appear to continue living within the host cell for brief periods of time. Sometimes they even undergo division within the vacuole.

Phagocytosis differs from emperipolesis as the engulfed cells are dead or dying cells or other materials from the extracellular space  (Option A and D). Phagocytosis also uses the host cell cytoskeleton to form pseudopodia and engulf the dead material. 

Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type (Option B). While cells that are internalized by this mechanism are initially viable, the majority of them undergo a non-apoptotic form of cell death.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury of his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Scald injury (damage from contact with hot liquids) that appears pink in colour, has oozing, and pain is suggestive of a 2nd-degree burn (i.e. partial-thickness burn). Collagen dressing is the most appropriate management for this injury.

The best dressing for burn wounds is skin; collagen is a good substitute for skin, especially in partial-thickness burns. For full-thickness burns, sequential excision and grafting should be considered.

Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied. 

Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing material, especially in partial thickness burns. 

If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream can be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be judiciously used and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree (superficial partial thickness) Second-degree (deep partial thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by ________
questions.solution:
The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by Frank Starling's law.

Length–tension relationship in cardiac muscle is similar to that in skeletal muscle. when the muscle is stretched, the developed tension increases to a maximum and then declines as stretch becomes more extreme. Starling stated that “energy of contraction is proportional to the initial length of the cardiac muscle fibre”. 

When cardiac output is regulated by changes in cardiac fibre length, this is referred to as heterometric regulation.

Conversely, regulation due to changes in contractility independent of length is called homometric regulation.

questions.text: Imaging of a patient with recurrent epistaxis shows the following finding. Which of the following statements is false about his condition?

choices.text: Tumor does not have a capsule
Digital palpation should never be done in OPD

questions.solution:
The image shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, which is called an antral sign or Holman-Miller sign. It is pathognomonic for angiofibroma. Recurrence of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is common. 

It is a rare tumor but is the commonest benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. It does not have a capsule. 

Digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, as it can lead to severe hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male undergoes polysomnography as part of his evaluation of OSAS. While reviewing his EEG you notice sawtooth waves, which are usually seen in ________
questions.solution:
Sawtooth waves in EEG are usually seen during REM sleep.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: A patient has a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of an accident 2 years ago, experiencing symptoms of pain and swelling at the site of injury, and an X-ray of the lower limb revealing sequestrum and involucrum in the tibia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of chronic osteomyelitis.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accidents). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare-up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone. It is formed when a fragment of bone gets separated from the healthy bone due to necrosis. It varies in size from a spicule to a large fragment and acts as a nidus for infection. It leads to abscess and persistent pus discharge in the bone. Sinus tracts are formed when the abscess from the infected bone drains out through the skin. 

The involucrum is the dense new sclerotic bone surrounding the sequestrum. It is formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. Cloacae are the perforations in the involucrum. Pus and tiny spicules of bone may be discharged through them.

The radiograph below shows sequestrum, involucrum and cloacae: 

Option A: Osteogenic sarcoma characteristically shows the sun-burst appearance and Codman's triangle, as shown below.

 

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma shows an onion-skin appearance of the periosteum, as shown below.

Option D: Multiple myeloma shows multiple punched-out lesions of the bone, as shown below.

questions.text: A patient with Frey's syndrome receives a Botox injection into the skin over the parotid region. Which of the following nerves has undergone aberrant innervation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Frey's syndrome occurs due to the aberrant innervation of the auriculotemporal nerve. It is also known as gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule.

During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands.

This results in sweating, warmth, and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

Management:

  • Antiperspirants - aluminum chloride
  • Tympanic neurectomy
  • Botulinum toxin injection into the affected skin

questions.text: The following structure was affected in a man diagnosed with a movement disorder. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of paralysis agitans(parkinsonism). The structure marked in the image is the substantia nigra in the coronal section of the midbrain.

questions.text: A 10-year-old came to the OPD with the following deformity of his left upper limb. What is the most likely cause of the fracture?
questions.solution:
The given image shows cubitus varus deformity, where the forearm has deviated medially in relation to the upper arm, which is a common complication of supracondylar humeral fracture.

Malunion is the commonest complication of a supracondylar fracture and results in a cubitus varus deformity, also known as gunstock deformity. This occurs when the fracture unites with the distal fragment tilted medially and in internal rotation. 

The image below shows gunstock deformity:

Cubitus varus is primarily a cosmetic concern with minimal functional impairment. Mild cases may not necessitate treatment, while severe deformities should be corrected through a lateral closed wedge osteotomy (French osteotomy).

Other options:

Option B: Olecranon fracture results from a direct injury as in a fall onto the point of the elbow. Complications include non-union, elbow stiffness, and osteoarthritis

Option C: Radial head fracture results from a fall on an outstretched hand and presents with pain over the lateral aspect of the forearm near the elbow along with restricted elbow movements, pronation, and supination. Complications include posterior interosseous nerve injury, myositis ossificans, and osteoarthritis.

Option D: Terrible triad of elbow refers to elbow dislocation with fracture of the radial head, coronoid process, and medial collateral ligament rupture.

questions.text: A patient comes to ER with a headache that he describes as the worst headache in his life. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The scenario described above is suggestive of a thunderclap headache seen classically in SubArachnoid Haemorrhage. Hence, it should be ruled out first. So, a non-contrast CT scan should be obtained within 72 hours, preferably at the earliest.

The extent and location of subarachnoid bleed on a non-contrast CT scan help locate the underlying aneurysm, identify the cause of any neurologic deficit, and predict delayed vasospasm.

Lumbar puncture prior to an imaging procedure is indicated only if a CT scan is not available at the time of the suspected SAH.

If CT/LP is positive - Proceed for a DSA > CT-Angiogram to localize an aneurysm.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 30-year-old fisherman was brought dead. His autopsy findings revealed emphysema aquosum. What is the most probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Emphysema aquosum is seen in cases of wet drowning.

Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. It is one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning.

The oedema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death. Hence, the lungs are held in the inspiratory position. The impression of the ribs on this overinflated lung leaves visible and palpable grooves on the lateral surface. 

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But, the absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aquosum - overinflation of the lungs
  • Paltauf’s spots - subpleural haemorrhages that reflect haemolysis within intra-alveolar haemorrhages
  • Dilation of the right heart and great veins - subjective and non-specific finding
  • Foreign material in the stomach - watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed or sand
  • Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - a positive non-specific sign of drowning
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning

Note: The autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

questions.text: Lithium usage in pregnancy can lead to which of the following teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Lithium use in pregnancy can lead to cardiac defects. 

Ebstein's anomaly is the specific cardiac defect with lithium use in pregnancy.

In Ebstein’s anomaly, the radiological sign seen is a box-shaped heart.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole  

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, tracheoesophageal fistula and fetal goiter
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants?

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.solution:
The curare group of drugs includes non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents that act by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors.

This leads to a decrease in the effect of acetylcholine and thus, neuronal transmission to the muscle does not occur. 

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OHA intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Other options:

Option A - Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Option C - Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option D - Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image?
questions.solution:
The given electrophoresis shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is classically seen in nephrotic syndrome.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with a chronic hepatitis B infection develops nephrotic syndrome. What would be the most likely pathology encountered in renal biopsy of this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the pathology would be membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy can be secondarily caused by Hepatitis B infection.

Membranous nephropathy:

Membranous nephropathy is a rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

  • It is classified as the primary, idiopathic form, where there is an isolated renal disease, or secondary, where nephropathy is associated with other identifiable systemic diseases or medications
  • In children, secondary form is far more common. The most common etiologies of secondary form are systemic lupus erythematosus or chronic infections. Among the latter, chronic hepatitis B infection and congenital syphilis are the best characterized and recognized causes.

questions.text: During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants, it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

  • LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in the function of neutrophils that include adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.
  • As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.
  • There is delayed separation of the cord, which is usually associated with infection of the cord stump.

There are three types of LAD:

  • LAD 1- Defective beta 2 integrin (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 
  • LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X, leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling.
  • LAD 3- Defective signaling for integrin activation, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. (milder than type 1)

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: A young sexually active man presented with multiple polypoid growths over his penis. Histopathological image of an excised lesion is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image showing papillary (villous) architecture with acanthosis, hyperkeratosis and koilocytosis of squamous epithelium, are characteristic findings of condyloma acuminatum.

Koilocytes have a prominent cell membrane, hyperchromatic resinoid nucleus, and perinuclear halo.

Grossly, they consist of single or multiple sessile or pedunculated, red papillary excrescences on the coronal sulcus, and the inner surface of the prepuce.

Option A: Condyloma lata is a maculopapular/nodular lesion seen in secondary syphilis.

Option B: Bowen's disease is carcinoma in situ of the penis characterized by the hyperproliferative epidermis and dysplastic epithelium.

Option D: Verrucous carcinoma / very well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, shows hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and keratin pearls.

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 1,2,3,4
  • Common warts (verruca vulgaris, plantar wart)
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text:
Laboratory investigations done in a chronic alcoholic patient are given below. Which of the following clotting factors is most likely to be normal in this patient?

Albumin - 3 g/dL

PT - 20 s

aPTT - 40 s
questions.solution:
All clotting factors are likely to be abnormal except factor VIII.

The liver is the site of production of the following factors:

  • Fibrinogen (factor I)
  • Thrombin (factor II)
  • Factor V
  • Factor VII (shortest half-life, hence PT affected first)
  • Factor IX
  • Factor X
  • Factor XI

Factor VIII is produced in the endothelial cells and factor XIII A-subunit is produced in the bone marrow.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. What is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Gradenigo’s syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. This is a complication of otitis media. 

The triad of Gradenigo's syndrome consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain  (5th nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

The incidence of this syndrome has reduced with the advent of antibiotics.

Option A-  Following acute coalescent mastoiditis the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and the external meatus and forms Luc's abscess. The swelling can burst into the meatus causing otorrhea.

Options B and C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and trigeminal schwannoma can present with cranial nerve palsy, but they do not follow the above clinical course.

Related Pearl: Signs of impending complication in attico-antral disease

Complication

Intracranial complication

Fever

Intracranial Complication

Intracranial Complication

Neck rigidity

Meningitis

questions.text: For years, a gold standard test (green curves) is being used for the diagnosis of the disease. Recently, a new test (purple curves) has been discovered and the researcher claims it to be a better test. Compared to the gold standard test, the new test has:
questions.solution:
The new test (purple curves) has higher sensitivity and higher specificity.

In the new test (purple curves), both false positives (FP) and false negatives (FN) have reduced.  

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN)

  • Sensitivity is inversely related to FN.
  • Therefore, reducing FN would increase the sensitivity.

Specificity = TN/(TN + FP)

  • Specificity is inversely related to FP.
  • Therefore, reducing FP would increase the specificity.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

These lesions appear as ovoid or spherical, often laminated, PAS-positive nodules within the mesangial core of the glomerular lobules.

These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman capsules (“capsular drops”).

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

1. Glomerular lesions:

  1. Capillary basement membrane thickening
  2. Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
  3. Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease

2. Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis

3. Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with acute onset fever and dysuria. Urinalysis reveals plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen is performed, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, along with the CT scan showing an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection, is suggestive of left-sided emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a severe, acute, necrotizing infection of the kidney caused by gas-producing organisms. It predominantly affects diabetic patients who are particularly susceptible due to their hyperglycemic state, which promotes bacterial growth and fermentation. The most common causative organism is Escherichia coli, which ferments sugar to produce carbon dioxide, leading to gas accumulation within renal parenchyma or perinephric tissues. Less commonly, organisms like Klebsiella and Proteus species can also cause this condition.  

Almost all patients present with fever, vomiting and flank pain. Patients frequently present with sepsis and ketoacidosis. If not treated early, it may lead to fulminant sepsis and is associated with high mortality. 

The diagnosis is primarily established radiographically, with a CT scan being the investigation of choice in identifying the extent of the emphysematous process and guiding management. The following diagnostic features are seen:

  • Enlarged, destructed renal parenchyma
  • Small bubbly or linear streaks of gas
  • Fluid collections, with gas-fluid levels
  • Focal necrotic areas with or without abscess

questions.text: Which of the following procedures involves burying the proximal stump into the myometrium?
questions.solution:
Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube followed by burial of the proximal stump into the myometrium. The distal stump is buried in the broad ligament.

Other options:

  • Uchida technique involves stripping the serosa from the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, followed by ligation and excision of the stripped portion. The proximal stump is buried in the broad ligament while the distal stump is left open to the peritoneal cavity.
  • Pomeroy technique involves forming a loop off the mid-portion of the tube followed by ligation at the base and excision. It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation.
  • Kroener procedure refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Meningioma is not commonly seen in MEN2B Syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is associated with meningiomas.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: GFR is increased by  _______
questions.solution:
GFR is increased by increased blood flow.

GFR = Kf ×Net filtration pressure

GFR = Kf ×[(PG − PB) – (πG - πB)]

Factors affecting GFR

  • Glomerular hydrostatic pressure (PG) and colloid osmotic pressure of the proteins in Bowman’s capsule (πB), which promote filtration.
  • Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman’s capsule (PB) and colloid osmotic pressure of glomerular capillary plasma proteins (πG), which oppose filtration.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting GFR

Determinants

Physiological/Pathophysiological Causes

↓Kf (filtration coefficient)→ ↓GFR

Renal disease, diabetes mellitus, hypertension

↑PB → ↓GFR

Urinary tract obstruction (e.g., kidney stones)

↑πG → ↓GFR

↓ Renal blood flow increased plasma proteins

↓PG → ↓GFR

a) ↑afferent arteriolar resistance (RA )→ ↓PG

↑ Sympathetic activity, (e.g., norepinephrine, endothelin)

b) ↓systemic arterial pressure(AP )→ ↓PG

 Arterial pressure

c) ↓efferent arteriolar resistance (RE )→ ↓PG

↓ Angiotensin II (drugs that block angiotensin II formation)

PG : Glomerular hydrostatic pressure

πB : Colloid osmotic pressure of the proteins in Bowman’s capsule

PB : Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman’s capsule

πG : Colloid osmotic pressure of glomerular capillary plasma proteins

questions.text: You are conducting a study on bactericidal activity of immune cells. You find that defects in the metabolism of a particular amino acid lead to dysfunction of nitric oxide production. Identify the involved amino acid.
questions.solution:
The involved amino acid is arginine, which is required for the production of nitric oxide (NO).

NO is an inflammatory mediator synthesized from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalyzed by NO synthase.

The given image shows the process of nitric oxide synthesis.

The co-enzymes of NO synthase are :

  • FMN
  • FAD
  • Heme
  • Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)

Three isoenzymes of NO synthase:

  • eNOS (endothelial nitric oxide synthase): Found in the endothelium and plays a role in vasodilatation. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.
  • nNOS (neural nitric oxide synthase): Found in the neural tissue and acts as a neurotransmitter. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.
  • iNOS (inducible nitric oxide synthase): TNF-α, IFN-γ and bacterial endotoxins induce hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils to produce this enzyme. It is inducible and calcium independent.

Functions of NO:

  • Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby produces smooth muscle relaxation.
  • Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and IFN-γ released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)
  • Neurotransmitter in the brain.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with Parkinsonism and cerebellar features. MRI showed the finding as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Parkinsonism, cerebellar features, and the 'hot cross bun' sign on MRI suggest multiple system atrophy (MSA).

MSA manifests as a combination of parkinsonian, cerebellar, and autonomic features. Based on predominant clinical features it is further divided into :

  • MSA-P:
    • Predominantly parkinsonian features are seen
    • T2 weighted MRI demonstrates hyperintense putaminal rim
  • MSA-C:
    • Predominantly cerebellar features are seen
    • MRI shows cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a child with fever, otalgia, trismus, and odynophagia with a normal external facial examination. The oral cavity shows congested and edematous tonsil and tonsillar pillars with edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. These findings are highly suggestive of quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). 

It is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen.

Patient presents with fever, unilateral throat pain, odynophagia, hot potato voice, torticollis, foul breath, referred otalgia through glossopharyngeal nerve and trismus due to spasm of pterygoid muscles.

Oral cavity examination may show congested and edematous tonsils, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. Edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. Pus may be seen on the tonsillar region. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes may be enlarged.

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 4 to 6 weeks later. 

Rare complications seen are parapharyngeal abscess, edema of the larynx, septicemia, lung abscess, or jugular vein thrombosis. 

Other options: 

Option A: Pharyngitis presents with fever, throat pain, enlarged tonsils, and lymphoid follicles on the posterior pharyngeal wall. 

Option B: Parotid abscess occurs due to the suppuration of parotid space. It presents with swelling, redness, firmness, and tenderness in the parotid area and at the angle of the mandible. It is usually unilateral, but bilateral abscesses can occur. Due to the thick capsule, fluctuation is often difficult to elicit. 

Option C: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.

questions.text: Which of the following bulges out in keratocele?
questions.solution:
In keratocele, the layer that bulges out is the Descemet’s membrane. Hence, it’s also called Descemetocele. It happens when the overlying layers are eroded by inflammatory processes secondary to infection. The Descemet’s membrane is resistant to inflammation and bulges out due to the intra-ocular pressure.

The bulging membrane may persist surrounded by a white cicatricial ring or may rupture.

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman was rushed to the ICU following an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There was no history of fever, night sweats or weight loss. MRI scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. MRI scan shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

It usually has multiple lesions in multiple locations which are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring; this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is also present.

Treatment includes sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Primary prophylaxis: It is given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given.

Secondary prophyaxis/maintanace therapy: It is given when CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL. Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. It is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are maintained >200/μL for 6 months.

Option A: Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen. MRI findings include dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts. 

Option B: Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients. On imaging, it is identified as a CT hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass, with MRI T1 hypointense, T2 iso- to hypointense, vivid homogeneous enhancement as well as restricted diffusion. 

Option C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, caused by JC virus, is characterized by demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the periurethral gland in males?
questions.solution:
Littre glands are the periurethral glands in males. These glands are numerous in the penile urethra. They secrete mucus prior to ejaculation which helps in lubrication.

Option A: Cowper's glands are the bulbourethral glands found in males. They are located lateral to the membranous urethra and opens via a duct into the bulbar urethra by piercing the perineal membrane. Their function is to secrete mucin during sexual arousal.

Option C: Skene's glands are the paraurethral glands found in females. These open on either side of the urethra. They are considered homologous to the male prostate.

Option B: Bartholin's glands are known as the greater vestibular glands in females. These glands are located in the posterior part of the vestibule and open through a duct into the vaginal orifice. They secrete mucus during sexual arousal for lubrication.

Clinical note: Since all these glands open via a duct into the orifices, any obstruction in the duct can result in cyst formation. They can get infected and necessitate removal.

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum

Vestibular bulbs

 		 Genital tubercle

Corpus cavernosum

Corpus spongiosum

Urethral and paraurethral glands /Skene's glands

Lower part of Vagina 		 Urogenital sinus  

Prostate gland
Greater vestibular glands/Bartholin's glands Urogenital sinus Bulbourethral glands/Cowper's glands
Granulosa cells Sex cords Seminiferous tubules and Sertoli cells
Round ligament Gubernaculum Gubernaculum testis
