Gartner duct (remnant structure) Mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct Epididymis, ductus deferens, and ejaculatory duct
Uterus, fallopian tube, cervix and the upper vaginal wall Paramesonephric duct/Mullerian duct Prostatic utricle and the appendix of testis (remnant structure)

questions.text: A baby was delivered at home in a village. Until which day of life should an ASHA worker visit this baby?
questions.solution:
Under the Home Based Newborn Care (HBNC) guidelines, ASHA workers should visit all newborns up to 42 days of life, according to the following schedule. 

Mode of delivery No. of visits Schedule of visits
Home delivery 7 Days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42
Hospital-based normal vaginal delivery 6

Days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

(except day 1)
Hospital-based LSCS delivery 5

Days 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

(except days 1, 3)

During her visits, ASHA workers must record weight, ensure vaccination, and registration of births. On completion of all these visits, they receive an incentive of Rs. 250. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient posted for emergency appendicectomy, the anesthetist grades him as Mallampatti class III and suspects a difficult airway. The device given in the image below can be used in this patient. The disadvantage of this device compared to an endotracheal intubation is:

choices.text: Risk of aspiration of gastric contents

questions.solution:
The given image shows a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) which is indicated in cases with difficult airways. The disadvantage of LMA is that it increases the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

LMA is used for airway management as a temporary, life-saving measure in patients with difficult ventilation. Difficult ventilation can be either due to difficult airways, unavailability, or difficulty in mask ventilation and intubation.

Advantages of LMA:

  • Less invasive as compared to tracheal tubes.
  • Lesser bronchospasm as compared to tracheal tubes 
  • It partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions.
  • Useful in difficult intubations
  • Less trauma to teeth and pharynx
  • Muscle relaxation is not required
  • Neck mobility is not required 

Disadvantages:

  • does not protect from gastric regurgitation
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of a gas leak and pollution

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O. 


 

Related Pearl: Different sizes of the laryngeal mask airway

Mask size Patient Size  Weight (kg) Cuff Volume (mL)
1 Infant <5 2-4
1.5 Infant 5-10 upto 7
2 Child 10-20 upto 10
2.5 Child 20-30 upto 14
3 Small Adult 30-50 upto 20
4 Normal adult(women) 50-70 upto 30 
5 Normal adult >70 30-40
6 Adults >100 50

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyze the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
The rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis is catalyzed by the enzyme, glycogen phosphorylase.

The process of phosphorolytic cleavage of the α1 → 4 linkages of glycogen to yield single units of glucose 1-phosphate, is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.

Glycogen phosphorylase requires pyridoxal phosphate as the coenzyme The phosphate group is catalytically active. There are different isoenzymes of glycogen phosphorylase in the liver, muscle, and brain.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with an elder sister with BRCA1 gene mutation presented to the OPD with a normal mammography report. Which of the following is the next preferred investigation to further evaluate this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, since the patient is at high risk for breast malignancy (first degree relative with BRCA1 gene mutation), MRI followed by trucut biopsy will be the appropriate next step for further evaluation.

MRI is helpful in the screening of high-risk individuals and is the most sensitive imaging modality. However, it should be done after initial radiological evaluation, in case the results are inconclusive.

American Cancer Society Risk Criteria for Breast Magnetic Resonance Imaging Screening:

Women at high lifetime risk (≈20%-25% or greater) of breast cancer-

  1. Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation
  2. First-degree relatives with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation, but have not had genetic testing themselves.
  3. Radiation therapy to the chest between the ages of 10 and 30 years
  4. Li-Fraumeni syndrome or Cowden syndrome or a first-degree relative with one of these syndromes.

Women with a personal history of breast cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ, lobular carcinoma in situ, atypical ductal hyperplasia, or atypical lobular hyperplasia, are at a moderately increased lifetime risk for breast cancer. 

Options A & D: Breast tomosynthesis or repeat mammography is not preferred as the next investigation in high-risk patients. 

Option C: Trucut biopsy will be done following MRI in high-risk patients.

Related Pearl: Breast Cancer Screening

Breast Cancer Screening

Individuals are encouraged to conduct a risk assessment by 25 years of age. This helps classify them into average risk or increased risk groups.

Recommendations: 

  1. Average-risk (no known genetic or family history of breast cancer)
    • 25-39 years of age: clinical breast examination every 1-3 years; 
    • ≥ 40 years of age: clinical breast examination and mammogram annually
  2. High-risk (positive family or genetic history of breast cancer)
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months after 21 years of age
    • Annual mammogram or MRI from 25 years of age or 10 years prior to the age at which the youngest family member was diagnosed with breast cancer (whichever is earliest)
  3. Asymptomatic women with previously treated breast cancer
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months
    • Annual mammogram
    • Annual MRI to be considered
  4. Mammogram and USG are not contraindicated in pregnant and breastfeeding women

High-risk patients for breast cancer:

  1. Women (or a first-degree relative) with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation or TP53 or PTEN genes
  2. Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations
  3. Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30
  4. Women with previously biopsy-proven breast cancer
  5. Women with ≥ 20% lifetime risk for breast cancer based on breast cancer risk models

*According to NCCN 2022 guidelines

questions.text: A 60-year-old man working in a factory for the past 30 years, presents with dyspnea and cough due to chronic exposure to a particular mineral agent. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows characteristic golden brown bodies with beaded and knobbed ends. All of the following are caused by exposure to this agent, except  ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing golden-brown asbestos bodies with knobbed or beaded ends is due to asbestos exposure. All of the given conditions are caused by exposure to asbestos except anthracosis. Anthracosis is a coal-induced pulmonary lesion.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung that occurs due to asbestos exposure. The disease usually manifests after a minimum of 10 years of exposure. Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Recurrent pleural effusions
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis 
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

Clinically, dyspnea and cough are seen. They can progress to respiratory failure, cor pulmonale, and even death. Chest radiograph can show irregular linear densities in lower lobes and in late stages can show a honey-combed pattern.

Histopathology shows diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and asbestos bodies. These appear as golden brown fusiform or rod-shaped beaded structures with a translucent center that is made of asbestos fibers coated by a proteinaceous material. They arise when asbestos gets phagocytosed by macrophages. Iron-protein complexes may coat other inorganic particulate matter to form ferruginous bodies.

The below image shows asbestos bodies.

 

Anthracosis is commonly seen in coal miners, urban dwellers, and tobacco smokers. It is caused by chronic exposure to coal dust. Wheeze is a typical finding seen in anthracosis. They can present with cough and, dyspnoea as well. Black carbon deposits in the lungs may be visible grossly as well as microscopically.

questions.text: An elderly woman on ART with a CD4 count of 35/μL and a high viral load presents with a 2 week history of cough, fever, and night sweats. She was diagnosed with pulmonary M. avium complex infection. Which of the following is not included in the triple-drug therapy for the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Triple drug therapy for pulmonary Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections does not include isoniazid.

Treatment for pulmonary MAC infection is triple-drug therapy with:

  • A rifamycin, like rifampicin or rifabutin (In HIV patients on ART, rifabutin is preferred)
  • Ethambutol
  • A macrolide, like clarithromycin or azithromycin

MAC infection is an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, occurring predominantly at CD4+ T cell counts of <50/μL and high viral load. The average CD4+ T cell count at the time of diagnosis is 10/μL. The most common presentation is disseminated disease with fever, weight loss, and night sweats.

questions.text: During the neurological examination of a patient, on shining light in his left eye, the left pupil does not constrict but the right pupil does. On shining light in his right eye, the right pupil constricts and left doesn’t. The defect is in:
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of left eye efferent (oculomotor nerve) defect.

The loss of pupillary light reflex (both direct and consensual) in the left eye associated with a preserved direct pupillary response in the right eye is characteristic of an efferent pupillary defect.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis is as shown. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?

pH- 7.24

pCO2- 60 mmHg

pO2- 52 mmHg

HCO3- - 27 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: An IT employee who has recently taken up the job is feeling guilty, hopeless and not able to concentrate on work. His symptoms started 3 years back when he started college. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The above scenario is consistent with the diagnosis of dysthymia.

Dysthymia / Persistent Depressive Disorder:

  • DSM V Criteria for diagnosis of dysthymia: Depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents - at least 1 year.

    Presence of two (or more) of the following while being depressed.

    • Poor appetite or overeating
    • Insomnia or hypersomnia
    • Low energy or fatigue
    • Low self-esteem
    • Poor concentration and/or difficulty making decisions
    • Feelings of hopelessness

    Early-onset, beginning in childhood or adolescence and in most cases by the age of 20 years. More common in unmarried and young persons with low income.

Cyclothymia:

  • A milder form of bipolar disorder which is chronic in nature.
  • Characterized by episodic mood swings of hypomania and mild depression.

Adjustment disorder:

  • It is an abnormal and excessive reaction to an identifiable life stressor.
  • It is a temporary condition
  • Eg: Feeling sad or hopeless in an exaggerated manner after a stressful life event. Inability to cope with stressful situations.

questions.text: During a rural health camp, a father brings a dull-looking baby with macroglossia and an umbilical hernia. On enquiry, you find out that the parents were told about a thyroid problem in the child at birth, for which they did not pursue any treatment. Which of the following is least likely to be found in children with the given condition?
questions.solution:
A dull-looking face with macroglossia, and umbilical hernia in a child with a thyroid disorder are all indicative of congenital hypothyroidism. Craniosynostosis is not seen in neonatal hypothyroidism. It is seen in hyperthyroidism.

Craniosynostosis refers to the premature fusion of sutures and closure of fontanelles and often results in abnormal, triangular facies. In congenital hypothyroidism, there is delayed closure of the fontanelles. Palpable goitre, though not common, can be seen in cases of untreated thyroid dyshormonogenesis.

questions.text: A patient presented with acute onset of weakness of the left arm which resolved completely in 10 days. He is known to have mitral stenosis, hypertension and dyslipidemia.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with mitral stenosis and acute onset weakness of the left arm is most likely to have had an embolic stroke, which is a type of ischemic stroke. Embolic strokes tend to occur suddenly with maximum neurologic deficit present at onset.

Mitral stenosis is known to cause atrial fibrillation and is a common cause of cardioembolic stroke.

Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina or cochlea. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes.

There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins crosses placenta?
questions.solution:
IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and provides natural passive immunity in the newborn.

  • Maximum placental transfer – IgG1
  • Minimum placental transfer – IgG2

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate was >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do?
questions.solution:
Ruling out glycemic extremes is the first step in the evaluation of this patient who is in a coma as most of the causes of coma are metabolic in origin and with appropriate treatment are completely reversible.

In this elderly patient, with no other relevant history, the most likely cause of coma is diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state, or even hypoglycemia (which may present with hypertension).

Other options :

The patient presents with tachycardia which is not a sign of raised intracranial pressure(bradycardia, altered respiratory pattern, raised systolic blood pressure) and hence starting iv mannitol (option 3) to reduce intracranial pressure or doing a CT (option 4) to rule out intracranial space-occupying lesion is not required.

The patient is a known case of hypertension which may cause hypertensive encephalopathy due to cerebral edema and would present with a similar history and signs of raised intracranial pressure giving antihypertensive (option 2)  medications would treat the condition but it is not the first step as metabolic causes are more common and have to be addressed first. 

Coma is defined as a deep sleep-like state from which the patient cannot be aroused.Coma could be due to:

  • Metabolic and toxic encephalopathies, where brain imaging will be normal
  • Meningitis syndromes
  • Diseases with prominent focal signs like stroke, or hemorrhage

Urgent intervention is needed to prevent further brain damage. It is done by providing supplemental oxygen, intravenous thiamine (at least 100 mg), and intravenous 50% dextrose in water (25 g) empirically. It is crucial to measure baseline serum glucose levels before administering glucose.

The initial examination includes evaluating the general appearance,vitals, breath sounds, response to stimulation, pupil size and responsiveness, and any abnormal posturing or movements. In trauma cases, the neck should be stabilized until ruling out cervical spine fracture. Airway protection and intravenous access is necessary. 

Immediate therapeutic intervention should be done for hypotension, significant hypertension, bradycardia, arrhythmias affecting blood pressure or marked hyperthermia. Signs of meningeal irritation or fever indicate the need for urgent lumbar puncture. Fundus examination for papilledema and a CT scan of the brain should be performed prior to lumbar puncture in comatose patients.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department complaining of depression and loneliness. History taking reveals that he does not engage in any social activity because he’s afraid of being rejected. Identify the likely personality disorder in this patient:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, as the patient does not engage in social activities due to fear of being rejected.

Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection leading to socially withdrawn lives, low levels of energy, easy fatigability, lack of enthusiasm, and inability to enjoy life.

Other options:

Option B: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by unwarranted suspicion, hypersensi­tivity, jealousy, envy, rigidity, excessive self-importance, and a tendency to blame and ascribe evil motives to others.

 Option C: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by shyness, oversensitivity, seclusive­ ness, avoidance of close or competitive relationships, eccentric­ity, no loss of capacity to recognize reality, daydreaming, and an ability to express hostility and aggression.

 Option D: Antisocial personal­ity disorder covers persons in conflict with society. They are incapable of loyalty, selfish, callous, irresponsible, impulsive, and unable to feel guilt or learn from experience; they have low levels of frustration tolerance and a tendency to blame others.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)

Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)

questions.text:
Ultrasound findings of a few patients are given below. Which of the following patients have oligohydramnios?

Patient 1 - AFI is 8 cm

Patient 2 - AFI is 4.5 cm

Patient 3 - SDP is 1.8 cm

Patient 4 - SDP is 2.7 cm

Patient 5 - SDP is 9 cm
questions.solution:
Among the given options, an AFI of 4.5cm (<5cm) or an SDP of 1.8cm (<2cm) indicate oligohydramnios.

Oligohydramnios means an abnormally decreased amount of amniotic fluid (liquor volume is <200ml). It is diagnosed using ultrasound parameters such as:

  • Single deepest pocket (SDP) - The largest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid identified in the sagittal plane on ultrasound is the SDP. The normal range of SDP is between 2 to 8cm. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed if SDP < 2cm.
  • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) - It is the sum of the deepest pocket of amniotic fluid from each quadrant of the abdomen. The normal range of AFI is between 5 to 25 cm.  Oligohydramnios is diagnosed if AFI < 5cm.

questions.text: Virulence of a disease is indicated by:

choices.text: Amount of GDP spent on control of disease

questions.solution:
Virulence of a disease is indicated by case fatality rate.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: What is the dose of ulipristal for emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
The dose of ulipristal is 30 mg tablet and it should be taken within 5 days of intercourse.

Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and acts by:

  • Preventing/delaying ovulation
  • Suppressing endometrial and follicular growth
  • Inhibiting implantation

Side effects are headaches and mood changes. It is contraindicated in women with severe hepatic dysfunction and severe asthma.

Note: The use of ulipristal for the treatment of fibroids has been discontinued due to the increased incidence of severe liver injury.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: You are asked to measure the degree of lateral curvature present in a patient with scoliosis using the method depicted below. Identify this method.
questions.solution:
In the given X-ray of a patient with scoliosis, the degree of lateral curvature is measured using Cobb's method. The degree of curvature of scoliosis on plain radiographs is measured using Cobb's angle.

To measure the Cobbs's angle, first locate the superior-end vertebra and inferior-end vertebra of the curve. Then draw perpendicular lines to the superior surface of the superior-end vertebra and to the inferior surface of the inferior-end vertebra.

The angle formed at the intersection of these perpendiculars is the angle of the spinal curve known as Cobb's angle. It can also be measured by measuring the angle made by the intersection of the end-plate lines. 

Note: Nash and Moe's method, Perdriolle and Vidal method, and Stokes method are methods of assessing vertebral rotation. 

Related Pearl: Important angles used in the diagnosis of Orthopedic conditions

Angles Conditions 
Carrying angle Cubitus varus and cubitus valgus
Baumann's angle Elbow fractures
Cobb's angle Scoliosis

Alpha angle

Beta angle

Southwick angle Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
Neck shaft angle Coxa vara
Q angle Patellar alignment
Kite's angle  Congenital talipes equinus varus

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles.  Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture showing pain in the calves occuring within a week of an upper respiratory tract infection (URI), with elevated creatine kinase levels suggests the diagnosis of viral myositis. The specific history of URI suggests influenza myositis.

Infectious myositis has a male predominance and is typically seen in young adults. Childhood form presents with fever, malaise, and rhinorrhea and is usually followed by severe pain, especially in the calves. The muscle pain is usually worse with movement and the symptoms last for about a week. In children, toe walking and wide-based gait may be seen because of the involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.

Other viral causes of myositis include HIV-1 (one of the most common causes of myositis), group B coxsackievirus (epidemic myalgia), HTLV-1 (Human T-lymphotropic virus), and cytomegalovirus (CMV). 

Lab features of influenza myositis include elevated CK which may be as high as 500 times normal the value. Urine myoglobin is usually positive. Detection of the virus with PCR testing of nasopharyngeal specimens can be carried out but is not of much clinical significance. The histopathological examination would reveal muscle fiber necrosis without much inflammatory change. 

Treatment includes bed rest, IV fluids, and symptomatic management with analgesics and antipyretics. Amantadine and other antiviral agents may be considered in adults. Complications include myocarditis and respiratory dysfunction. Rhabdomyolysis is an uncommon complication.

questions.text: How long is thyroxine stored in thyroid follicles?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine is stored in the thyroid follicles for 2-3 months, bound to thyroglobulin. 

Serves as a reserve of T3 and T4, thus delaying the occurrence of hypothyroidism, if thyroid secretion ceases.

questions.text: The given image shows a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) of a 3-year-old boy. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children
Both males  and females are affected
Antenatal USG would have shown oligohydramnios
Transurethral ablation of leaflets can be done

questions.solution:
The given image of an MCU shows dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects corresponding with the valves. This is suggestive of a posterior urethral valve. The posterior urethral valve affects only males.

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are obstructing membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra, which hinders the outflow of urine from the urinary bladder. It may precipitate chronic renal disease in children. It is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in male newborns.

Antenatal USG would show oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.

On performing an MCU, the posterior urethral valve appears as a sharply defined perpendicular or oblique lucency in the distal prostatic urethra. The posterior urethra is dilated and elongated with a shield-like appearance. The bladder is trabeculated with clear demarcation of the hypertrophied bladder neck.

Children with PUV who are not diagnosed before birth may present with delayed voiding or a poor urinary stream. Infants are predisposed to repeated UTIs. Other common signs and symptoms may include a palpable abdominal mass, failure to thrive, lethargy, poor feeding, urosepsis, and urinary ascites. Older boys may have persistent diurnal incontinence or abdominal distention. Physical examination of the newborn reveals a palpable bladder. 

Transurethral ablation of leaflets is done in older boys who have a posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: Which of the following beta lactam class has shown activity against MDR-TB?
questions.solution:
Carbapenems have shown activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Note: Until recently beta-lactams were assumed to lack action against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. However, carbapenems in conjunction with clavulanate have demosntrated efficacy against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the gynecology OPD for a routine Pap smear. The histopathology slide is shown below. Identify the cell marked as "A".
questions.solution:
The cell marked A is the superficial cell. 

ACOG guidelines recommend cervical exfoliative cytology every 3 years starting 21 years as screening for cervical cancer.

The image below shows a superficial cell (a) and an intermediate cell (b):


The image below shows parabasal cells (marked by black arrows):

 

Koilocytes are epithelial cells that contain eccentric, hyperchromatic, moderately enlarged nucleus that is displaced by large perinuclear vacuole. It is a feature of HPV infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who is a smoker presents with complaints of gastric reflux for the past 3 months. Endoscopy and biopsy results are as shown in the images given below. Which among the following histopathological images correctly represent the carcinoma which this patient would most likely develop?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus which has the potential to transform into an adenocarcinoma in the future. The slide B correctly represents an adenocarcinoma of esophagus showing tubular glands infiltrating the lamina propria and the squamous epithelium.

The given endoscopy reveals patches of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction.
The histopathological slide shows the intestinal type mucosa (left) replacing the normal squamous esophageal mucosa.
Hence a diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus can be confirmed.

Other options:

  • Slide A – Represents a normal squamous esophageal epithelium
  • Slide C – Represents a squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus. On high power, keratin pearls are characteristically seen in SCC.
  • Slide D – Represents a squamous papilloma of the esophagus which is a benign entity.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves provide sensory supply to middle ear cavity?
questions.solution: The sensory supply to the middle ear cavity is provided by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve. It forms the tympanic plexus with the caroticotympanic nerves from the internal carotid plexus of the sympathetic fibers.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

The below image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura.

 

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

In heavy infections of 200 adults worms or more (trichuris dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false?

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Quincke-type lumbar puncture needle. Coagulopathy is a contraindication to perform lumbar puncture (LP).

Contraindications for LP include:

  • Patients receiving anticoagulant or antiplatelet medications and those with coagulation defects
  • Possible raised intracranial pressure
  • Suspected spinal epidural abscess
  • Infection at the site of puncture

Before performing an LP, it is important to assess the patient's bleeding risk by checking their platelet count, international normalized ratio (INR), and partial thromboplastin time (PTT). LP is considered contraindicated if the platelet count is less than 20,000/μL, and some institutions recommend a platelet count of greater than 40,000/μL before proceeding with the procedure.

Proper positioning of the patient is crucial for an LP. The patient should lie on their side away from the examiner, with their knees bent and pulled up toward the abdomen (lateral decubitus). The neck should be gently bent forward, and the shoulders and pelvis should be aligned vertically. LP is typically performed at or below the L3-L4 interspace, which can be identified by palpating the spinous processes and using a line drawn between the posterior superior iliac crests as a guide.

Alternatively, the LP can be done with the patient seated upright, leaning forward to flex the back. This position is suitable for obese patients.

After sterile preparation of the insertion site and the injection of a local anesthetic, the LP needle is inserted midline between two spinous processes, with the bevel parallel to the dural fibers facing upwards. The needle is advanced until the subarachnoid space (SAS) is reached indicated by a loss of resistance. Once the SAS is reached, the opening pressure is measured, and CSF is allowed to drip into collection tubes for analysis.

A traumatic tap may cause a bloody tap, which can be differentiated from subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) by examining the supernatant after centrifugation. Prior to needle removal, the stylet is reinserted to prevent nerve entrapment and the development of a dural CSF leak. There is no need for prolonged recumbency after the procedure to prevent post-LP headache.

Neuroimaging is recommended before performing an LP in patients who have an altered level of consciousness, focal neurological deficits, new-onset seizures, or papilledema. This is because these patients are at a higher risk of developing cerebellar or tentorial herniation, a rare but potentially fatal complication. Imaging studies should also include the spine in patients with symptoms suggestive of spinal cord compression, such as back pain, leg weakness, urinary retention, or incontinence. In cases where acute meningitis is suspected and neuroimaging is necessary before the LP, it is recommended to administer antibiotics, preferably after blood culture, before conducting the imaging study.

The image below shows Quincke (dura cutting) and Whitacre (dura splitting) LP needles:

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
The given ECG showing a wide QRS complex tachycardia with waxing and waning QRS amplitude points to the diagnosis of torsades des pointes. As the patient is hemodynamically stable, intravenous MgSO4 is the treatment of choice.

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) has a continually changing QRS morphology. Polymorphic VT that occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired prolongation of QT interval is referred to as torsades des pointes. Patients present with near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest.

IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and the prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades des pointes.

If magnesium alone is ineffective, isoproterenol infusion or pacing, to a rate of 100-120 depolarization/minute usually suppresses VT recurrences.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation
Used in unstable PSVT, atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation, and ventricular tachycardia with a pulse Used in ventricular tachycardia without a pulse, and ventricular fibrillation.
Shock is delivered in sync with the R wave (in absolute refractory period) Shock is delivered at any time during the cardiac cycle.
Monophasic - 100 to 200J Monophasic - 360J
Biphasic - 50 to 100J Biphasic - 120 to 200J

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

questions.text: A child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Very long-chain fatty acids are accumulated in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, also known as Zellweger's syndrome, is a rare inherited disorder characterised by the absence of peroxisomes in all tissues. It is caused by mutations in the genes encoding peroxins, which take part in peroxisome biosynthesis. There is accumulation of C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues along with generalised loss of peroxisomal functions. Patients present with severe neurological symptoms and most die within a year. Other biochemical findings include abnormalities in the bile acid synthesis and a decreased plasmalogens.

questions.text: Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen in:
questions.solution:
Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are both seen in apoptosis.

Apoptosis has two pathways:

Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway Death receptor or extrinsic pathway
Activation inside the cell  Activation outside the cell 

Occurs in response to:

  • DNA damage
  • Radiation
  • Infection

Involved in:

  • Elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes
  • Killing of target cells by cytotoxic T-cells

Involves release of pro-apoptotic proteins (BAX, BAK)

They form a BAX-BAK channel in the mitochondrial membrane

Involves death receptors on cell surfaces (have a death domain)

These include TNF-1 and Fas (CD95) of the TNF family

Leakage of cytochrome-c results in the formation of Cyt.c-APAF1 complex, followed by apoptosome formation

FasL on T-cells binds to Fas bind adapter proteins via death domain

Activation of caspase 9

Activation of caspases 8 and 10
Both pathways converge into a common pathway that involves the activation of caspases 3, 6, 7 (executioner caspases)

APAF-1 - Apoptosis activating factor-1

TNF - Tumor necrosis factor

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria demonstrates tumbling type of motility at 25 °C, but is non-motile at 37 °C?
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes demonstrates a tumbling end-over-end motility at 22–28 °C but becomes non-motile  at 37 °C. This is because the peritrichous flagella are produced optimally at lower temperatures but not at 37 °C.

questions.text: You note the given finding in a baby admitted to the pediatric ward. Which of the following defects in the intrauterine life is the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Failure of the intestinal loops to return from umbilicus
Defective closure of body wall in the abdominal region
Defective closure of body wall in the pelvic region
Defective closure of the vitellointestinal duct

questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is cloacal exstrophy, which is caused by the failure of the body wall to close in the pelvic region. 

The given image shows the classic feature of cloacal exstrophy, which includes an exstrophic central bowel area flanked by two hemibladders:

  • Bladder exstrophy: The bladder is seen turned inside out (exstrophy means turned inside out) and visible as 2 hemibladders on either side. 
  • Bowel exstrophy: The central defect is the prolapsed intestinal loop that appears as the elephant trunk deformity. The central bowel field usually contains an ileocecal segment that has prolapsed. 
  • In addition, omphalocele can be noted in the umbilical region in this image.

Exstrophy of the bladder or cloaca occurs due to abnormal closure of the body wall in the pelvic region:

  • Exstrophy of the bladder: The bladder mucosa is exposed to the surface. In male infants, epispadias is seen additionally.
  • Exstrophy of the cloaca: The closure of the ventral body wall is more severely affected than in bladder exstrophy. There is the involvement of the bladder and rectum, both of which are derived from the cloaca. In addition, there is defective development of the urorectal septum leading to anal canal malformations and imperforate anus. As the genital swellings are widely separated, external genitalia will be defective.

Cloacal exstrophy can present as part of OEIS syndrome, in which multiple anomalies are seen, where O stands for Omphalocele, E for Exstrophy of bladder or cloaca, I for Imperforate anus, and S for Skeletal anomalies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the OPD with headaches and high blood pressure. On investigation,  increased aldosterone levels with low renin levels are seen and a diagnosis of Conn's syndrome is made. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Rise of  > 7meq/L in plasma Na+ level

questions.solution:
Rise in plasma Na+ level of > 7meq/L than the normal value is least likely to be found in this patient.

Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually a rise of less than 4-6 mEq/L. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.

Conn’s syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-producing tumour of the zona glomerulosa, causing:

  • Loss of potassium by the kidneys leads to hypokalemia.
  • Mild metabolic alkalosis.
  • A slight increase in extracellular fluid volume and blood volume.
  • A modest increase in plasma sodium concentration.
  • Hypertension.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The provided history of falling on an outstretched arm and the X-ray revealing an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint point to the diagnosis of Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. 

Patients present with pain, swelling, and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was brought to the casualty after being found lying on the street, muttering to himself, and cursing at bystanders. His MMSE score was 20. Physical examination findings are shown below. After admission, it is known that he has severe diarrhea and vomiting. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of dementia (MMSE score of 20), diarrhea, and dermatitis in sun-exposed areas like the forehead, neck (Casal's necklace), and hands are seen in vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency also known as pellagra. 

The neuropsychiatric symptoms of pellagra include apathy, irritability, insomnia, depression, and delirium.

Option A: Myxedema madness is a rare presentation of hypothyroidism characterized by depression, hypomania, and schizophrenia. Diarrhoea and vomiting are usually not seen.

Option C: Acute intermittent porphyria is characterized by periodic abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, psychotic features, tachycardia. There is no photosensitivity in acute intermittent porphyria.

Option D: Thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke’s encephalopathy which manifests as an acute neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait, or can cause Korsakoff syndrome which manifests as a chronic amnestic syndrome characterized by severe anterograde amnesia and confabulation.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?
questions.solution:
Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space. Trismus is seen in pre-styloid abscess due to the involvement of medial pterygoid muscle.

Parapharyngeal space is divided into two compartments by the styloid process and its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

In a post-styloid abscess, there is a bulge of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, accompanied by paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X (resulting in vocal cord paralysis), XI, XII, and the sympathetic chain, which can manifest as Horner's syndrome. Swelling in the parotid region may also be present. Notably, trismus, the inability to fully open the mouth, is usually absent in this type of abscess.

A pre-styloid abscess exhibits distinct features including the prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa, along with trismus caused by the spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle. Marked odynophagia is common. Additionally, an external swelling can be observed behind the angle of the jaw.

Fever, sore throat, torticollis (caused by spasm of the prevertebral muscles), and signs of systemic toxicity are common features.

Diagnosis can be established using a contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT). If there is suspicion of thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or an aneurysm of the internal carotid artery, magnetic resonance arteriography (MRA) can be useful.

Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible.

The image attached below shows the components of both spaces:

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the knee came for a follow-up visit. On examination, the following findings were noted. Identify the marked lesion.
questions.solution:
The above image showing the knob-like appearance of the proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) in a patient with OA is suggestive of Bouchard's nodes. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling.

Heberden's nodes develop in distal interphalangeal joints (DIP).

The images below show Bouchard's (yellow arrow) and Heberden's nodes (black arrow).

questions.text: A young boy from Africa comes with complains of fever, night sweats and a swelling over the jaw. On biopsy of the lesion, histopathology showed a starry sky appearance. Cytogenetics revealed a t (8;14) translocation. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings of starry sky appearance and cytogenetics showing t(8;14) translocation point to a likely diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. 

Burkitt's lymphoma is a type of non-hodgkin's lymphoma. It arises from mature germinal center B-cells that express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6. It is one of the fastest growing tumors, with a high doubling time.

It can occur in 3 forms mainly preseting in children or young adults:

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. 
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it most often appears as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukemia - it is seen in immunocompromised individuals

All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are associated with increased MYC protein levels due to translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. Depending in the translocation partner common chromosomal abnormalities are:

  • t (8;14) causing MYC-IGH fusion - most common 
  • t (8;22) causing MYC-Kappa fusion
  • t (2;8) causing MYC-Lambda fusion

The tumor shows a high mitotic index with numerous apoptotic cells. The nuclear remnants of these apoptotic cells are phagocytosed by interspersed benign macrophages. The phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic starry sky pattern.

Despite being an aggressive tumor, it responds well to intensive chemotherapy. Chemotherapy with EPOCH-R (rituximab, infusional etoposide/vincristine/doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, prednisone) is highly effective.

The image below shows the starry sky appearance seen in Burkitt's lymphoma.

questions.text: A patient is brought with bleeding from a deep penetrating wound in his right thigh. His pulse is weak and 100/min, BP is 90/60 mmHg. The skin on his extremities is cold and clammy. Which of the following is the best method of restoring adequate cardiac output and tissue oxygenation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of hemorrhagic shock.

In the case of hemorrhagic shock, the most effective method of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by locating and stopping the source of bleeding.

Volume repletion will allow recovery from the shock state only when the bleeding has stopped. The first-line agents are crystalloids.

Since the patient already has cutaneous vasoconstriction, vasopressors are not administered without prior adequate fluid resuscitation to avoid further vasoconstriction and gangrene formation.

Nearly 70% of the body’s total blood volume is estimated to be located in the venous circuit. Compliance of the venous system involves a relationship between venous volume and venous pressure. This pressure gradient drives venous flow and therefore the volume of venous return to the heart. Blood loss depletes this component of venous volume and reduces the pressure gradient; consequently, venous return is reduced.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: A nurse is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. These findings denote which of the following?

choices.text: Concurrent hepatitis B and hepatitis E infection

questions.solution:
Seropositivity for both HBsAg and HBeAg indicates an acute hepatitis B infection.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is present for about 3-4 weeks. It may be present in a chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). Antibody to HBsAg (Anti-HBs) is detected 3-6 months after recovery from the initial infection or vaccination and confers immunity.

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is a marker of active viral replication in the liver. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

In high infectivity chronic HBV, both HBsAg and HBeAg will be present but in low infectivity chronic HBV only HBsAg will be present.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman has a history of papillary thyroid carcinoma left untreated for 2 years. She complains that the rapid enlargement in her neck swelling over the last month has made it difficult for her to swallow and talk. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Local invasion of the surrounding structures

questions.solution:
An elderly woman with rapidly enlarging neck mass and dysphagia in the setting of an untreated papillary carcinoma suggests a diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid cancer.

Anaplastic thyroid cancer, a poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma, is the most aggressive cancer and has the worst prognosis of all thyroid malignancies. 

It usually occurs in elderly females. The typical manifestation is an with rapidly enlarging neck mass, dysphagia, and cervical tenderness. Patients usually have a history of untreated differentiated thyroid carcinoma (DTC). Local invasion to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) causes hoarseness. It may also cause tracheal obstruction. Distant metastasis is more common in the lungs via the hematogenous route.

Diagnosis is made by FNAC. However, trucut/open biopsy is frequently used to confirm the diagnosis in cases of doubt.

Management:

  • If metastasis is absent: Total thyroidectomy + LN dissection
  • If metastasis is present: Palliative care with chemotherapy and radiotherapy
  • If tracheal obstruction: Isthmectomy to relieve obstruction

questions.text: A young man with a history of motion sickness presents to your OPD with upcoming plans for a road trip. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Ondansetran one night before and also before trip

questions.solution:
Scopolamine (Hyoscine) transdermal patch is the most appropriate treatment for motion sickness before a trip.

It should be applied behind the ear about 5-6 hours before the journey, and gives protection for around 72 hours against motion sickness, after which the patch can be replaced if necessary.

Scopolamine is also used for narcoanalysis as it causes sedation and amnesia.

Dimenhydrinate is a first-generation antihistamine that can also be used in motion sickness. Although dimenhydrinate may have equal efficacy it is not preferred because of its sedating properties.

questions.text: A  patient presented with acute worsening of edema of the left hand, which was present for the past 5 years. Her surgical history was relevant for a radical mastectomy with radiation therapy for left-sided breast carcinoma. On examination, the limb appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Stewart–Treves syndrome.

The development of angiosarcoma after a combination of postmastectomy lymphedema and radiation therapy is known as Stewart–Treves syndrome. It can arise de-novo or in association with post-mastectomy lymphedema. It presents with acute worsening of edema with subcutaneous nodules which are hemorrhagic or ulcerative.

Treatment is preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation of arm). The prognosis is poor.

Option A: Tietze syndrome is an inflammatory condition characterized by chest pain and swelling of the cartilage around the ribs at the costochondral junction. 

Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that affects the muscle tissue, mostly in children and adolescents.

Option D: Milroy's disease is a familial disease, caused by congenital abnormalities in the lymphatic system. Disruption of the normal drainage of lymph leads to fluid accumulation and hypertrophy of soft tissues.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with the following painless and foul-smelling ulcer. On examination, there is no lymphadenopathy. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no lymphadenopathy points to a diagnosis of granuloma inguinale. It is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis also known as Klebsiella granulomatis.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change.

questions.text: A 45 year old iron smelter, presents to the OPD with history of rice water diarrhoea. The image shows the clinical finding that the doctor notes during examination. Which of the following clinical features would be consistent with the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning. Tremors are consistent with a diagnosis of arsenic poisoning which should be suspected in a patient of with Aldrich Mees lines, red velvety mucosa, and rice water stools.

Hyperpyrexia, Hyperpigmentation, and Anorexia are associated features.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was brought by his parents to the ER. The parents complained that the child had been lethargic for a few hours and unresponsive for the past 30 mins. They give a history of 4-5 episodes of vomiting in the past one day. On examination, the baby had tachycardia, tachypnea, and very slow capillary refill time. The pediatrician asks you to initiate IV fluid therapy with a 24G IV cannula. Which colour IV cannula would you use?
questions.solution:
The color of the 24 G cannula is yellow. 24 G cannula is usually used for paediatric age group.

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic smoker comes with acute epigastric discomfort for the past one hour. ECG shows ST-segment depression. What is the immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of a non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS). Immediate intervention is the administration of aspirin.

Aspirin is the first drug given in acute coronary syndromes. An initial dose of 325 mg to be chewed and swallowed is given. If oral administration is not feasible, it should be given as a rectal suppository.

The following protocol must be followed in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome:

  1. Stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation
  2. Administration of O2
  3. Treatment of sustained ventricular arrhythmia rapidly according to ACLS protocols
  4. Give aspirin 325 mg
  5. History and examination, assess cardiac biomarkers
  6. Give three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets each 5 min apart. Add IV nitroglycerin for the persistence of symptoms.
  7. Treat left heart failure if present with an after-load reducing agent or loop diuretic
  8. Give beta-blockers
  9. Give morphine for the persistence of anxiety and discomfort related to MI
  10. In patients with STEMI - Reperfusion with PCI or fibrinolysis (if PCI is unavailable within 120 min) followed by antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy. In patients with NSTEMI - antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy are indicated.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the ER with a history of RTA. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is hyperresonant on percussion with decreased breath sounds. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen was soft. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of trauma with decreased breath sounds and a hyper-resonant note on percussion indicates pneumothorax. The presence of tachycardia, hypotension and elevated JVP is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. 

Tension pneumothorax develops when there is a parietal or visceral pleural tear. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters the pleural space from the lung or chest wall during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration, leading to the collapse of the affected lung.

It is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, acute dyspnea, sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness), neck vein distention, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, decreased chest movements on the affected side, hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side and absent or decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed awaiting radiological confirmation.

Management includes:

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy with a wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line.
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th intercostal space in the triangle of safety.

The triangle of safety is bounded anteriorly by the lateral border of the pectoralis major, posteriorly by latissmus dorsi and inferiorly by a horizontal line at the level of the nipple.

The X-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side.

Other options: 

Options A:  Pericardial tamponade can mimic tension pneumothorax, but the absence of a tympanic note on percussion rules out its possibility. A patient with pericardial tamponade can present with hypotension, raised JVP, and muffled heart sounds (Beck’s triad), with normal breath sounds and no tracheal shift.

Option C: Dullness in percussion at the base of the left inferior angle of scapula in conjunction with tubular breath sounds (Ewart’s sign), chest pain that improves while sitting upright and worsens when lying down and pulsus paradoxus are indicative of pericardial effusion. Pericardial effusion develops into tamponade when the effusion leads to increased pressure, impairing ventricular filling and reducing cardiac output.

Option D: Massive hemothorax is the accumulation of >1500 ml of blood or one-third or more of the patient’s blood volume in the chest cavity. The patient will have collapsed neck veins, decreased breath sounds and a dull note on percussion.

questions.text: The following scan is of a young woman on oral contraceptives. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image given is of hepatic adenoma.  It is the most frequent hepatic tumour in young women on oral contraceptive pills. 

Hepatic adenomas, also referred to as hepatocellular adenomas, are benign liver tumours. They are well-defined vascular lesions, which are generally solitary. They are almost always seen in women between the age of 25 and 50 years and are associated with the use of the oral contraceptive pill.

On CT, uncomplicated adenomas are usually homogeneous, with a well-defined margin. They enhance markedly and uniformly during the arterial phase and then merge with the surrounding liver during the portal phase.

Hepatic adenoma on the CT scan is shown below.

 

Other options:

Option D:  On contrast-enhanced CT scan, hemangiomas show asymmetrical, nodular peripheral enhancement that is isodense with large vessels and progressive centripetal enhancement. Liver hemangioma on CT scan is shown below.

Option B: Most metastatic deposits appear as areas of low attenuation on unenhanced CT and portal-phase CT. Hypervascular tumours are often visible as low-attenuation lesions on unenhanced images and may enhance transiently in the arterial phase, some becoming invisible in the portal phase. Metastatic infiltrates in the liver in the portal phase on CT scan are shown below.

Option A: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) typically shows a decreased signal on T1-weighted images and a moderately increased signal on T2-weighted images, with internal heterogenecity. MRI is regarded as the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting HCC. Given below is the MRI image of HCC:

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: The function of malachite green used in Lowenstein-Jensen media is to:
questions.solution:
Malachite green is the selective dye present in the LJ medium to prevent the growth of contaminants.

The selective media for Mycobacterium tuberculosis is Lowenstein–Jensen medium (LJ) medium.

Contents of LJ medium:

  • Malachite green (Prevents growth of contaminants)
  • Egg (provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism of mycobacteria).
  • Mineral salt solution (acts as a buffer)
  • Glycerol (Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis).
  • L-asparagine (Source of Nitrogen)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line medication for an elderly patient with hypertension?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate first-line antihypertensive among the given drugs is chlorthalidone.

Thiazide diuretics are recommended as one of the first-line antihypertensive drugs for elderly patients without any comorbidities. Among them, guidelines recommend chlorthalidone over hydrochlorothiazide because of its longer duration of action. 

First-choice drugs used in the treatment of hypertension in patients without any comorbidities include:
  • ACE inhibitors or ARBs: No evidence of superiority of one class over the other. However, ACE inhibitors have a higher risk of side effects like dry cough and angioedema.
  • Calcium channel blockers: Extended-release, long-acting dihydropyridines are preferred. 
  • Thiazide diuretics: Chlorthalidone is usually preferred to hydrochlorothiazide.

Loop diuretics like furosemide and torsemide are less effective antihypertensives than thiazides. They are not indicated for the routine management of hypertension.

In the presence of any associated conditions or comorbidities, the first choice drugs for the treatment of hypertension would be as follows:
 
Comorbidities
First choice drugs for hypertension

Chronic kidney disease with proteinuria
