questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency with a BP of 160/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 120. CECT done reveals a Stanford A aortic dissection. What is the initial management of this given condition?
questions.solution:
The initial management of patients with all types of aortic dissection is beta blocker medication to control hypertension along with pain management. Patients with Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) will require surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta.

Predisposing factors: 

  1. Age
  2. Hypertension
  3. Marfan syndrome
  4. Pregnancy
  5. Other connective tissue disorders, for example, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus
  6. Coarctation of the aorta
  7. Turner or Noonan syndromes
  8. Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic). 

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Contrast-enhanced CT is currently the most preferred imaging modality for aortic dissection. Double-lumen aorta is seen on CECT. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for patients who are unstable for transportation.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of aorta Type II Type A

Descending the aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Management of aortic dissection:

The initial management of patients with all types of aortic dissection is beta-blocker medication to control hypertension along with pain management. The preferred beta-blocker drug is esmolol. Hemodynamic stability is an important consideration.

  • Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.
  • Stanford Type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. For patients with complicated type B dissection, percutaneously placed endovascular stents are currently preferred. Surgery is reserved for the rare patients not suitable for stenting.

Other options:

Options B and D: Low molecular weight heparin and vitamin K inhibitors are contraindicated in aortic dissection as they can worsen the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: A child presents with a history of severe sunburns just after a few minutes in the sun.  Severe freckling is noted in the sun-exposed areas as shown below. The autosomal recessive condition responsible for this is due to:
questions.solution:
The image and history point to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by Defective Nucleotide Excision repair.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure. This leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

In XP the skin is normal at birth and has a three-stage progression:

  • Diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle-like areas over the sun-exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.
  • The second stage is characterized by poikiloderma. This results in skin atrophy, telangiectasias with mottled hyperpigmentation, and hyperpigmentation.
  • In the third stage appearance of cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma. 

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin. XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.

Other options:

Option A: Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ) is seen in Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID).

Option C: Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER) leads to MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP).

Option D: Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR) causes Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came to the local emergency department with severe headache and stiffness of the neck. The CSF specimen is cloudy. While in the emergency room, an intern performs gram stain of the CSF but by mistake forgets the step in which iodine is added. Assuming that the women has meningitis caused by streptococcus pneumoniae,  how would the bacteria on the intern’s slide appear?

choices.text: No gram stain results would be obtained due to lysis of all cells

questions.solution:
In the above question, the intern forgot to add iodine, i.e., the second step of gram staining. As a result, the purple iodine-dye complex will not form, and the entire crystal violet dye will wash away during the decolorization step. Now when the safranin is added, all the cells will stain red.

The various steps in gram staining are as follows:

  • The crystal violet dye (basic dye) stains all cells purple.
  • The iodine solution (a mordant) is added to form a crystal violet–iodine complex. At the end of this step, all cells continue to appear purple.
  • In the decolorization step, the organic solvent, such as acetone or ethanol, extracts the blue dye complex from the lipid-rich, thin-walled gram-negative bacteria to a greater degree than from the lipid-poor, thick-walled gram-positive bacteria. At the end of this step, the gram-negative organisms appear colorless; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.
  • The red dye safranin (counterstain) stains the decolorized gram-negative cells red/pink; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 34-year-old male who was newly diagnosed with HIV is being evaluated prior to initiation of antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following techniques is used to determine the CD4+ cell count in his peripheral blood?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is used to determine the CD4 count in the peripheral blood.

Flow cytometry is a laser based method which analyzes the cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules which are named as per cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature.

There are about 300 types of CD molecules. Monoclonal antibodies against specific CD molecules are tagged with fluorescent labels. Incubation of the cells with a variety of different CD labeled antibodies allows the flow cytometric analysis of distinct populations of cells in the mixture.

Flow cytometry is routinely used in identifying CD4-positive cells, CD8-positive cells, B cells, macrophages, and cells expressing a variety of cytokines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of the prick. Histology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genus Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Points in favor:

  • Sub-Himalayan belt farmer with thorn prick injury
  • Verrucous growth
  • Histology showing "Medlar bodies"(sclerotic bodies)

 

  Chromoblastomycosis Sporotrichosis
Cause Pigmented fungi-Phialophora and Fonsecaea species Dimorphic fungi-Sporothrix schenckii
Presentation Warty, cauliflower-like growth at the site of the prick A linear chain of ulcerating nodules and sinuses along the lymphatics
Histology Medlar bodies/sclerotic bodies Asteroid bodies

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form, which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of foot

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry cervix is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Vaginal itching and green frothy discharge in a young female with strawberry vagina points towards trichomoniasis. Metronidazole is the drug of choice for trichomoniasis.

It is is the most common parasitic infection in humans in the industrialized world.

It is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, an anaerobic, flagellated protozoa, exists only as a trophozoite (no cyst stage).

Diagnosis is made by detection of motile flagella during microscopic examination of wet mounts. Direct immunofluorescent antibody staining is more sensitive (70-90%) than wet mount.

Culture is done on Feinberg-Whittington media.

Treatment: DOC- Metronidazole 2 gm single oral dose. All sexual partners must be treated to prevent reinfection, especially from asymptomatic males. Tinidazole can also be used for the treatment of trichomoniasis.

The image below shows strawberry vagina seen in trichomoniasis:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the hormonal contraceptive in Norplant II?
questions.solution:
The hormonal contraceptive present in Norplant II/Jadelle is Levonorgestrel.

Norplant II/Jadelle is a subdermal implant with two rods, each containing 70 mg of levonorgestrel. The hormone is released at a rate of 50 mcg per day. It provides contraception for 3-5 years.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: The given logo belongs to which of the following programmes?

choices.text: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the National Programme for Prevention & Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NP-NCD), which was earlier called the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

NPCDCS was launched in 2010 in order to prevent and control major NCDs (non-communicable diseases). It focuses on strengthening infrastructure, human resource development, health promotion, early diagnosis, management, and referral. NCD Clinics are being set up at District and CHC levels, to provide services for early diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up for common NCD. NP-NCD has specialized facilities at the district hospital level. At the subcentre level, screening and referral are done.

The NP-NCD has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states. For the cancer component, there is the Tertiary Care Cancer Centers (TCCC) scheme, which aims at setting up/strengthening State Cancer Institutes (SCI) and TCCCs all over the country, to provide comprehensive cancer care in the country. 

Note: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has been integrated with this programme in 2021.

Other options:

Option A: The logo below shows Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram

Option C: The logo below shows Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission

Option D: The logo below shows Family Planning Campaign

questions.text: Frotteurism is __________

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.solution:
• Frotteurism is obtaining sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs etc. in crowds etc). It is punishable under Section 292 BNS (290 IPC, with a fine of up to 200 Rs). Under the BNS, it is permissible to be fined up to Rs. 1000.
  • Eonism (also known as Transvestism) is a sexual perversion where a person's whole personality is dominated by a desire to be identified as a member of the opposite sex. Usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes. There is no hormonal/genital abnormality.
  • Transsexualism: It is the desire to become members of the opposite sex and seek surgery for anatomical alterations.
  • Exhibitionism:  It involves behaviours over a period of 6 months or more, involving the exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. This is a punishable offence. Section 296 BNS (294 IPC with imprisonment up to 3 months or fine.)
    Under the BNS, this is punishable with imprisonment up to 3 months, or a fine of Rs. 1000, or with both.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy came with complaints of 6 patches on back and on left arm that were hypopigmented with the loss of sensation. Which of the following is the treatment for this case?

choices.text: Rifampicin (450mg) + Dapsone (50mg) + clofazimine (150 mg) monthly and 50 mg alternate days
Rifampicin (450 mg)+ Dapsone (50mg) + clofazimine (150 mg) monthly and 50 mg daily
Rifampicin (600mg) + Dapsone (150mg) + clofazimine (300 mg) monthly and 50 mg daily

questions.solution:
The presence of 6 patches on back and on left arm that were hypopigmented with loss of sensation suggest multibacillary leprosy.

According to the NLEP recommended multidrug therapy regimens for Hansen disease Multibacillary (LL, BL, BB) in pediatric patients.

Rifampicin 450 mg

Dapsone 50 mg

daily
Clofazimine 150 mg

Clofazimine 50 mg

alternate days

The duration of therapy is 6 months in paucibacillary and 12 months in multibacillary leprosy among children aged 10-14 years. Clofazimine is administered on alternate days.

questions.text: In which of the following surgeries would you expect the least surgical site infection rate?

choices.text: Removal of urinary stones in a patient who has no UTI

questions.solution:
A surgical site infection (SSI) rate is the least in clean wounds, i.e in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Among the given options, only option b, uncomplicated hernia surgery is a clean wound.

Elective cholecystectomy and removal of urinary stones in a patient who has no UTI are examples of clean contaminated wound.

Emergency appendectomy is a contaminated wound

SSI rates relating to wound contamination with and without using antibiotic prophylaxis.

Type of surgery

Infection

rate without

prophylaxis (%)

Infection

rate with

prophylaxis (%)

Clean (no viscus opened)

 1-2 1-2

Clean-contaminated(viscus opened, minimal spillage)

 6-9 3

Contaminated (open viscus with spillage or inflammatory disease)

 13-20 6

Dirty (pus or perforation, or incision through an abscess)

 40 7

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: Gastrin is produced maximally from which part of the GIT?
questions.solution:
Gastrin is produced maximally from the G-cells in the antral portion of the gastric mucosa.

Gastrin exists in 3 forms containing 34, 17, and 14 amino acid residues called G34, G17, and G14 gastrins respectively. The G17 gastrin is the principal, most abundant form.

questions.text: Identify the gas cylinder based on the pin index shown.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Pin index system (3,5) of Nitrous oxide. 

Pin index system (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

  • Each gas cylinder has two holes (except entonox) in its cylinder valve that fits the corresponding pins in the yoke of the anesthesia machine. The relative positioning of the pins and holes is unique for each gas which constitutes the pin index system.
  • The PISS should only be considered as partial protection because pin index failures have been reported due to bent or broken pins.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: On auscultation you hear a high pitched diastolic murmur over the left sternal border, a collapsing pulse on palpation and oral cavity examination reveals a pulsatile uvula. Which of the following pressure volume loops demonstrates the findings that you would expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option 'B' (representing image C) demonstrates the expected features of Aortic Regurgitation.

Collapsing pulse (water) on palpation, Pulsatile Uvula (Muller’s Sign) and a Diastolic murmur over the left sternal border point towards Aortic Regurgitation.
The clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation.

In aortic Regurgitation, there is loss of the isovolumetric phases of ventricular action due to continuous flow across the aortic valve i.e the isovolumetric relaxation has backflow from aorta to ventricles -> ventricular volume is not constant but keeps increasing. The isovolumetric contraction phase too initially has backflow across the valves as ventricular pressure is less than aortic pressure.
Thus, both isovolumetric phases are lost.

Also, the end systolic volume is increased in Aortic regurgitation unlike in mitral regurgitation where it is reduced.

Related Pearl: Surface Marking of the Heart Valves

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings  on the anterior surface of lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The given image and the clinical features of red tender swellings in a patient with Crohn’s disease are suggestive of erythema nodosum.

The most common infectious cause of erythema nodosum is group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus infection.

Aetiological factors in erythema nodosum:

  • Infections: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, leprosy, Brucella, toxoplasmosis, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, CMV, E. coli, Yersinia, tuberculosis
  • Idiopathic, pregnancy
  • Drugs including oral contraceptives, hormonal replacement therapy, sulphonamides, and penicillin
  • Sarcoidosis, SLE, RA, Reiter's syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease
  • Malignancy

It is the result of a non-specific cutaneous reaction to various antigens. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. The prodromal phase includes fever, joint, and muscle pains, and an alteration in general health. It is followed by the development of painful, tender, nodules on the extensor surfaces of the legs, knees and forearms. It usually resolves spontaneously in about 10 days. Treatment is mostly supportive.

The image below shows erythema nodosum.

Dermatologic manifestations of IBD are as follows:

Option A) Pyoderma gangrenosum: UC > CD, runs a course independent from bowel disease activity. Begins as a pustule, ulcerates circumferentially, is seen commonly on the dorsal surface of feet and legs, and may occur on arms, chest, and face.
Option C) Sweet’s syndrome: acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in UC.
Option D) Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is often seen in immunocompromised patients such as those with neutropenia. It presents as a round/oval lesion, 1 to 15 cm in diameter, with a halo of erythema and a necrotic center.

questions.text: A 30 year old man comes with the complaints of difficulty in swallowing and food getting stuck in his throat. He also gives a history of atopic dermatitis. The endoscopic finding of the patient is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given endoscopic image shows multiple esophageal rings, longitudinally oriented furrows, and punctate exudate, which are the hallmark findings in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The symptoms of food impaction and dysphagia, along with the history of atopic dermatitis also point towards the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis:

  • Chronic immunologically mediated disorder
  • Symptoms: Adults- food impaction, dysphagia; children- feeding intolerance, GERD-like symptoms.
  • The cardinal histologic feature is epithelial infiltration by large numbers of eosinophils
  • Endoscopically evident rings in the upper and mid portions of the esophagus
  • Typically refractory to high-dose proton pump inhibitor treatment.
  • Most patients are atopic- may have atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, and peripheral eosinophilia.
  • Treatment: dietary restrictions to prevent exposure to food allergens, such as cow milk and soy products, and topical or systemic corticosteroids.

questions.text: What is the maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through a peripheral vascular line in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Through a peripheral vascular line, a maximum of 12.5% dextrose can be infused.

The dextrose concentration greater than 12.5% has an acidic pH and can cause irritation to the peripheral veins, which can lead to thrombophlebitis.

Note:

Central vein lines can be used for 25% D if needed.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, her serum biomarkers are found to be normal except for LDH, which is found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a 16-year-old female presenting with an ovarian mass and raised LDH, points towards the diagnosis of dysgerminoma.

Dysgerminoma corresponds to the seminoma of the testis and accounts for 3-5% of all ovarian tumors. It usually arises in young girls or in children, with an average age of 20 years. It is the most common malignant tumor of the ovary. It is usually unilateral, but they are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%) and can be found at gonadal or extragonadal sites. 

Genetics: 

  • Express OCT-3, OCT-4 and NANOG
  • Activating mutations in the KIT gene in one-third of cases

Pathology: 

  • Solid neoplasm with areas of softening due to degeneration with fleshy consistency 
  • Mimics the pattern of the primitive gonad, lymphocytic infiltration is seen

It presents with abdominal pain, distension, a palpable mass and ascites. Some tumors occur in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase, lactate dehydrogenase and beta-HCG, but no sex hormones.

Morphology and histology:

  • Most dysgerminomas (80% to 90%) are unilateral tumors ranging in size from barely visible nodules to masses that virtually fill the abdomen.
  • On cut surfaces, they have a solid yellow-white to gray-pink appearance and are often soft and fleshy.
  • Like seminoma, it is composed of large vesicular cells with clear cytoplasm, well-defined cell boundaries, and centrally placed regular nuclei.
  • The tumor cells grow in sheets or cords separated by scant fibrous stroma, which is infiltrated by lymphocytes and may contain noncaseating granulomas

 The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes. 

 

Management: 

  • Though dysgerminomas are radiosensitive, they are contraindicated due to ovarian destruction in young girls. It is employed only for residual and recurrent tumors.
  • Treatment includes surgical removal and postoperative chemotherapy.

Chemotherapy comprises of 

  • Injection bleomycin 15 mg i.v (or) i.m weekly for 12 weeks 
  • Injection etoposide 100mg/m2 1-5 days every 3 weeks 
  • Injection cisplatin 20 mg/m2 1-5 days 3 weeks 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Option A: Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option B: Segmentation and mixing help in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option D: Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below.
